div.p: THE FEMALE PRINCE; OR, FREDERICK OF SICILY.
In Three Parts.
LONDON, Printed for H. Rodes next door to the Bear Tavern near Bride Lane in Fleettreet. 1682.

div.head: TO THE Right Honourable THE COUNTESS OF CONWAY.
div.p:
IT is now become o general a Cutome to Devote things of this nature to ome eminent
Patronage, that uch as appear in the World without a coniderable Protector, eem like men abandoned by their good Genius, run a kind of Gauntlet, and lye expoed to the lahes of every Satirical Wit. Thus, Madam, having found o much Innocence and Beauty in this Story, as made me think it Merited a better Detiny; I have preumed to make
an Offering of it to your Ladyhip, in hopes that the entertainment it may afford, will both atone for the confidence of this Addres, and ingage your Ladyhip to allow it your Favour and Countenance. I was eaily made enible, that it could be no where o ure, as in uch a Sanctuary, ince o many Illutrious, even Divine Qualities conpire to the Compoing
your Ladyhips Character, that it would be a kind of Prophanation to attach it, when owned by a Peron of your Fame and Merit. For it is not only, Madam, all the advantages of Wit and Beauty, of Alliance and Extraction, that have procured you that Univeral admiration in the World; your Ladyhip is as much renowned for the Qualities
of your Mind, as you are for thoe of Body and Fortune, inomuch that all the Incene the Age can afford is not ufficient to Celebrate o much Merit and Virtue, nor am I able to expres the repect and Devotion with which I am,

closer.signed: Your Ladyhips mot Humble and mot Obedient Servant F. S.

div.head: THE FEMALE PRINCE; OR, FREDERICK OF SICILY.
PART I.
div.p:
SIcily enjoyed great Satisfaction in the Reign of Menfroy; that Prince having all the Qualities which obtain the Admiration of the People. He had render'd himelf formidable both in Spain and Italy, and tho' he had no other Enemies than thoe his Valour had occaioned,
he had already given everal Battels; and it is certain, that he conquered as often as he fought. Queen Caandra, his Wife, Daughter of Roger King of Naples, was likewie an accomplih'd Princes, having all the Virtues that can be wih'd for in a Great Queen; and the King, who loved her with an extraordinary Affection, would have had nothing more to deire, if Heaven had not deprived him of everal Princes whom the Queen had brought into the World. This misfortune of their Family, made a great part of their Lives very afflicting, Daughters not being capable of Succeeding in the Crown, that Kingdom mut inevitably have fallen into the hands of Berranger, King of Majorca, Minorca, and Terra Nova, his Couin-German, and greatet Enemy.
Thee two Kings being extraordinarily animated againt one another, would never have upended the Effects of their Hatred, if Prince Ordogne, Count of Barcelonna, and their Allies, had not made them agree to a Truce, which they repreented to be neceary for the Repoe of their People. The King of Sicily, notwithtanding the Advantages he had over Berranger, was prevailed with to conent to this Propoition; for indeed, continual Victory does almot as much weary the Conquerour as the Vanquihed; and the King of Majorca being brought into Depair, through the ill Succes of his Arms, accepted though with Repugnance, all the Conditions that the King of Sicily impoed upon him, hoping, that by the Length of the Truce, he might
the better put himelf in a Poture of reiting the Forces of Menfroy, who had almot exhauted all thoe of his Kingdom. Thoe kind of Treaties that are made out of Neceity do not put an end to Quarrels, they only help to foment them, and the Moment of eeing them revived, is impatiently expected. Such were the Sentiments of Berranger, and which he endeavoured to inpire, as much as poible, in young Amaldee his Son, and the young Camilla, as oon as they came out of their Nures Arms. The King of Sicily being returned to Meina, the place of his uual Reidence, found the Queen his Wife ready to lye in. This Princ • s, who through the los of her Children, was become inenible of any Joy, received the King with all the Tendernes he was capable of, but
with a Languihing and Dejectednes that cannot be conceived. The King made it his Buines to divert her Grief, putting her in hopes that Heaven would be more favourable to them, and that it would perhaps conerve the Child with which he went; but, if by Misfortune he was delivered of a Girl, he was reolved to conceal her Sex, and to bring her up as a Prince Majeur, a Name conecrated in Sicily, as the Prince of Wales in England, for to exclude Berranger from hopes of ucceeding in his Crown. The Queen did willingly agree to this Deign; and ome days after, he was brought to Bed of a Princes, who was called Frederick, a Name famous in Sicily. The Nure, Governes, and the Lord High Admiral, were the only Perons who had the Secret of this important
Mytery. The Queen dyed ome time after, whoe Los, occaioned a publick Affliction, the King being infinitely grieved, and received no Conolation, but what the ight of Frederick afforded him; of whom, he took a mot particular Care. And indeed, never was Prince better bred than this; his Natural Endowments being polihed by a good Education, quickly rendred him the mot accomplihed of all thoe of his Age. He was a Prodigy of Beauty; but his Wit urpaed the Charms of his Peron, whereof, he gave early and coniderable Intances.

The young Prince of Naples, called Leon, who was brought up with Frederick, walking one day with him, and eeing a Number of fair Ladies, attended by a Throng of Courtiers, they continued
their Walk, with great Indifference as to thoe who followed them; which Prince Leon taking notice of, You mut confes, aid he to Frederick, that we are no great Gallants, ince we are o olitary in the Preences of o many Beauties. You are in the right, replyed Frederick; we might at leat agreeably employ our Eyes, though our Hearts are not yet in a State of being eniible; but it is perhaps, the little Peril we hould thereby run, that makes us o negligent of puruing it. The Truth is, dear Couin, aid Leon to him, with an Ingenuity altogether charming, I am very far from running any uch Danger; and hitherto, I find in my elf o little Dipoition to Love, that it would require a great deal of time to prepare me for the leat Sence of it. There
needs no more, replyed Frederick gallantly, than two Eyes, and perhaps not o many Years, to make you change your Stile. But you, aid the Prince of Naples once again, Do not you find omething urprizing in what they tell us of Love, whom they decribe to us as an Infant, and however, would peruade us, that he is a dreadful Enemy? I know not what to think of it, aid Frederick to him, but perhaps we hall find him more formidable when we are les childih. It was thus that thoe two lovely Princes entertained themelves at the Age of twelve Years. In the mean while, Endeavours were ued to inpire Frederick with as much Indifference as was neceary for the Peronage he was to repreent; and more particularly, they ininuated into him, that to reign
peaceably upon his Throne, it was requiite he hould reign over his own Heart. The King his Father had taken Care to intruct him betimes with the Reaons of his Diguie; and had made him promie, that during his Life, and that of Berranger, he would never dicover what he was, for the depriving his Enemy of the Hopes of ucceeding him in Sicily. Frederick embraced thee Sentiments, and knew no other Paion than that of reigning. At length, having attained to the Age of eventeen Years, he was intructed in all the Exercies that are in ue with Men; wherein, he o excelled, that he eemed the mot accomplihed Prince of his Time. His Stature, though tall for a Woman, was middle eized for a Man, but o full of Sweetnes, that it was impoible to forbear being
charmed with it. His Eyes were black, parkling, and weet, mingled with a Flame, and an engaging Languihing: in hort, all his Peron was compoed after uch a manner, as was capable of inpiring the mot inenible with Affection. Having attained to that Seaon wherein Love commits o many Diorders, he began to oberve himelf more trictly, well knowing, that if that Paion was o much to be avoided by all People, it was much more o for him, who would be obliged to keep very perplexing Meaures with thoe hould have rendred him enible. He aw daily a number of handome Princes, and having examined himelf, he did not yet find any Motions, which he could be any ways apprehenive of. Beides, he imagined that his Diguie heltring him from
the Gallantries of Lovers, would likewie ecure him againt the Attempts of Love: but therein he was mitaken in his Accounts. He quickly perceived by the Conquets that his good Meen had made, that a Paion may be produced without the help of another. Several Beauties ighed for him in ecret, and ome, openly enough to make themelves undertood; inomuch, that the Crowd of his Mitrees importuning him, he imagined, that his bet Coure would be to diemble an Intrigue, by which means, he would deprive them of their Hopes, and by Conequence, divert the Deigns they might have upon his Heart. Beides, being peruaded that Gallantry is very becoming a young Prince, he was willing to affect a Paion, whoe Appearances could be no ways troubleome.

Yolanda, the Lord High Admiral's Daughter, eemed the mot proper for his Deign, he was aimable enough to imagine her elf beloved, upon the leat Declaration, and young enough not to ditinguih a real from a feigned Paion. Nor was he deceived in all thee Conjectures. Yolandeck loved him in good Earnet, and all thoe who might have been capable of puruing any Deigns againt the Liberty of this Prince, and who had made too much hat to preent him with their Hearts diengaged themelves as oon as they perceived that he payed his Vows to this Lady. Only Amedea, the Lord Admiral's econd Wife, whom her Huband had never acquainted with the Cheat that was put upon all the Earth, was deceived therein as well as others; and likewie, oberved
more Charms in the Peron of Frederick, ince her Daughter-in-Law had eemed to her to have a Kindnes for him. She aw him every day; and finding his way of loving very delicate, he endeavours to divert Vows that were only imaginary. She was beautiful, and had not yet attained to thirty Years, which is not an Age to dicard Lovers: And tho' her haughty and imperious Carriage would have dicouraged all thoe whom her Beauty had made her Conquets; he imagined, that by abating omething in Favour of the Prince, he would make him the more value what he did only for his ake; wherefore, her Eyes poke, but poke to no purpoe. When Love does not make it elf known to a Heart, it is Death to the Language of the Eyes: there wanted a Clearer Explication
with Frederick, who was free from any amorous Impreion. But, the Admiral's Lady was not of a Humour, to proceed o far; and her Paion being contrained to contain it elf within the too narrow Bounds, which her Haughtines precribed, it manifeted it elf by cold and depiing Looks, which he had the Confidence to treat that Prince with, when he came to pay her Viits out of Devoir, that he might ee, at the ame time, her Daughter-in-law, whom he had ever in her Eye, ince the Dicovery he had made of her Amour with Frederick.

In the mean while, the paionate Yolanda was forbidden to look upon the Prince of Sicily as a Lover: But, he choe rather to deprive her elf of o dear a Sight, han to conider as an other man,
the Peron whom her Heart had found o excelling; and went to a Houe her Father had, ome Leagues from Meina, where heltring her elf from the Perecution of her Mother-in-Law, he imagined, that by a little Abence, he hould the more inflame the Paion of her Lover.

In the mean time, the Prince of Sicily eeing how eaie it was for him to engage Hearts, he now grew willing to pare them out of Pitty. He had no other Intrigue during the time of Yolanda's abence, having too little Acquaintance with Love to amue himelf any longer with uch kind of Follies. Hunting was his greatet Divertiement, wherein, Prince Leon was his contant Companion. As they were one day returning from running a Stag, they aw a Veel trangely battered by
the Winds and Waves, which having forced it everal times againt the Rocks, notwithtanding the skill of the Pilots, it was going infallibly to uffer Shipwrack; whereupon, they ent their Servant, who with Boats took up ome Perons from the Wracks of this unfortunate Ship; and Frederick
having informed himelf concerning them, with an unuual Curioity, he was told, that they were apparently Perons of Quality, which their Air did ufficiently bepeak them. Frederick, by I know not what Intinct, being moved and concerned at their Misfortune, beeeched the King his Father to end for them to Court. Immediately, they were provided with all things neceary; for all they had been able to do, was only to ave their Lives, and their Baggage was lot with
the ret of their Train. Leon came to the Palace a little before they arrived there, and having found out Frederick, they were dicouring of the Pleaure they had had in Hunting, when they aw two perons come in equally well made, who drew their Eyes, and thoe of all the Court, being a man of a very high Appearance, accompanied with a very beautiful Lady, who, notwithtanding the Sadnes and Grief that their Shipwrack had caued in them, failed not to give Birth to far greater Dangers than that they had newly ecaped. Leon was dazzled, and truck with the Beauty of o charming a Peron; and looking upon Frederick, he oberved in his Eyes the ame Trouble with which he was agitated; he imagined to have found at the ame time, a Mitres and a Rival; inomuch
that Jealouie and Love did together make their entrance into his Heart. We may ay, that the Princes of Sicily found at the ame moment, what rendred her both tender and uneaie, he aw a man o well made, that he might in ome manner jutifie the urprize of her Senes; He had the Noblet and finet hape that ever was, and above all, he had a Majetick Air, which the Princes entertain'd a deign of vanquihing; but coming to cat her Eyes upon the Fair One who accompanied him, he could not forbear letting looe a Sigh. It was the firt he had tarted, that was hared between Spight and Love. This Lady had almot all the Features of him we have poken of, but her white Hair, and her languihing Countenance, did hinder at firt the Company's taking
notice of the Reemblance that was between them. How did that paionate Air, inpired in all probability by him who began to pleae the Princes of Sicily, appear to her an ill Omen, and how retles began he to be from that time! On the other ide, the Princes of Majorca, for it was he and her Brother, who had newly ecaped drowning, was enible at the ight of Frederick, of a certain tender motion which he could not defend her elf from. In hort, thoe three Hearts which were taken in that ame moment, eldom met in the equel. Menfroy received them with all imaginable Civility. But they did not think convenient to make themelves known, before they were well acquainted with the Humours of thoe Perons who treated them o obligingly; they
contented themelves with giving to undertand, that they were of coniderable Extraction, but that they were contrained by coniderable Reaons to conceal till, for ome time, their Names and their Fortune. They imagined, that they two only of all the Company being aved, they could not eaily be dicovered, and that their Ship having been unk, the Sicilians had not had the leiure to take notice of the Colours. They found it no hard task to gain Credit in all they aid of their Extraction, their Carriage and their Air did ufficiently hew it: People only upected there might be ome Gallantry between Perons whoe Union was only occaioned by their Birth. But it is time to give an account how they were conducted into the Territories of Sicily.

Prince Ardalin Count of Barcelona, being paionately in love with the Daughter of Berranger, whom he had een at Majorca, where he had reided ome time. He procured her conent to become his Wife: the Princes Camilla having a great Eteem for him, and being ingaged in no Paion, received his Vows with great Civility; which Ardalin's Paion made him take for omething more delicate. Being at length obliged to return to Barcelona, he made her promie to be mindful of the Sentiments he had for her; and in a hort time after, his Ambaadour demanded her in Marriage of the King her Father, who finding the Match advantageous, did willingly give his conent. The Ceremonies that are uual being performed, they embarked, and Prince Amaldee
being deirous to conduct his Siter into Ardalin's Dominions, embarqued in the ame Veel that was newly cat away upon the Coat of Sicily. Ardalin was expecting with great Impatience, o dearly beloved a Bride, while that the Caprice of Fortune and of Love poeed her elewhere. Camilla was at firt ight charmed with the Beauty and good Meen of Frederick, and thought it would be Injutice to refue him, what he called Eteem. The Hatred of their Family, which he had from her Birth, ought to hinder her from entertaining any thing too intereing; for which Reaon, he abandoned her elf to Motions, which he imagined were in no wie to be feared: and beides, being defended by her natural Coldnes, which had hindred her from making any other
Returns to Ardalin's Paion, than what meer Good Will afforded; he could not be peruaded that it would make any greater Progres: but, Time made her know, that the Eteem he had for Frederick, was too particular for to be only meer Eteem; and comparing the Sentiments he had for him, whom he durt not o much as wih for her Lover, with thoe he had for the Prince who was to be her Huband, he found therein o great a Difference, that it amazed her. How! aid he, hall the unfortunate Camilla leave her Heart in Meina, while that he goes languihing and deolate to pend her Days at Barcelonna; that mut not be. Let us endeavour at leat, to defer o fatal a Marriage; let us implore the Friendhip of a Brother, without dicovering to him, however,
what ought to be concealed from us our elves. Whereupon, he aroe to go to his Apartment, when Prince Leon came into her's, with Deign to prepoes her in his Favour, by preventing his pretended Rival in his Declaration, whom he fancyed to have ever eluded, by beieging her continually. He found her o thoughtful and o dejected, that he had not the Power to peak to her; and thee two unhappy Lovers, remained in a Silence, that would have melted with Pity all thoe who hould have oberved them; yet whereof they themelves did hardly take notice.

Prince Amaldee diverted them from it by his Arrival. He came to confer with his Siter about •• e means of facilitating their Departure: Leon being hindred by his Preence, from puruing his Deign,
deferred the Declaration thereof, expecting a more favourable Juncture.

But the Princes of Sicily being alarmed and confued, to find I know not what new Motions in her Heart, which he could in no wie approve of, did all that was poible, to render them ecret. That young Princes being accutomed to feign what he had not yet been enible of, found it difficult to conceal this real Affection. All the Court did quickly oberve this Change of her Humor, which was imputed, with great Probability, to Yolanda's Abence; who, upon the Rumour of o tender an Effect, was willing to put an end to their mutual languihing, by retoring to him her Sight, and enjoying his: the Coure he was, however, to teer was pretty nice in the Conjuncture
of things. The Admiral's Lady, whom Frederick's Sadnes did put very much out of Humor, was more to be feared than ever; but a Mitres does little value the Dipleaure of a Mother in Law. Beides, a Friend he had at Court, who had given her Notice of the Condition the Prince was reduced to, propoed to her a ecret Interview between them, which it was eaie for her to procure: whereupon, he returning to Court, did heap up Troubles on the mierable Frederick, who had too many Misfortunes of his own, for to be in a Condition to pity thoe of others. The Princes of Sicily did eaily perceive, that notwithtanding the Complaiance of Amaldee, he had a terrible Averion for all the Nation, and which this Princes did not fail to apply to her elf in particular,
through the ingular Interet he took therein: though he looked upon Camilla as her Rival, he failed not to pay her Viits very often, that he might ee there her Lover, who notwithtauding his Indifference, appeared to her very lovely. She came once thither jut as Prince Leon, in Depair of having found Camilla o ill dipoed to hear him, was riing for to be gone. Camilla changed colour at the ight of Frederick, who bluhed at the ight of Amaldee, and Leon, out-raged to ee all this Diorder, reolved to tay there till, that he might oberve Motions that put him upon the Rack. Amaldee alone had o atifyed an Air, that the Princes of Sicily thought him the mot happy of all men; and after a light Coveration, her Heart full of Sighs, which he found difficult
to tifle, and her Eyes moit with Tears, which he could no longer contain, he went away, not being able to upport the ad Reflection he made upon Amaldee's Happines. But, the Princes Camilla had other Sentiments of this o precipitated Departure; and, having well oberved the Diorder of Frederick in the Preence of her Brother, he imagined, and applauded her elf in ecret, for being the Caue of it. Amaldee being left alone with his Siter, for Leon went away a Moment after Frederick, propoed to her the continuing of their Voyage, and told her, that they had remained too long in an Enemies Country, that it was requiite they hould be gone with the oonet, and that too towards Barcelonna, where Prince Ardalin impatiently expected them. Camilla trembled
at this Dicoure, and putting all in practie for the deferring till, for ome Time, that terrible Departure, he made him conent, though with great Repugnance, to all he had a Mind.

In the mean while, he reolved to dipatch, privately, ome one to the King his Father, for to give him notice of all that had happened ince their Departure; and going out omething diatified with his Siter's Change of Humor, he went to walk alone in the Palace Gardens.

Immediately, he heard ome confued Voices; and approaching omething nearer, he ditinguihed that of Frederick, and that of Leon, who were parleying omething harply. I congratulate, aid the Prince of Naples, your having made a Conquet, without being at the Trouble of the leat
Advance; your Vows are received before they are declared; and there is no pretending to any other than the Quality of an unfortunate Lover, if a Man had a mind to engage in Sicily. Frederick had too many Affairs in his Mind to think of undeceiving him; inomuch, that he replyed with ome Sharpnes, As you did not conult me about the Choice of your Engagement, I do not think my elf obliged to give you an Account of the Progres I hall make in mine; but believe me, let us continue Friends, a trange Lady hould not diunite us; you ought not to undertand me all together, but you hall know the ret, when it is fitting for me to tell it you. Then he quitted him for to go into a gloomy. Alley, where, letting a Looe to his Melancholy Humor, he remained
in a certain Scituation, wherein, the Soul, as it were, being preyed upon by it's Lanquour, is rendred almot inenible, wherein we fly, if I may o ay, from our elves, to give our elves up to the beloved Object, the Crowd of Thoughts, hindring us from being able to ditinguih any one, and by having too much to reolve on, we reolve on nothing.

In the mean while, the Prince of Majorca imagining that the two Princes were his Siters Lovers, he went to inform her of it, without thinking, that uch Advertiements do ever further an amorous Paion intead of preventing it. Siter, aid he, gallantly to her, You ought to be upon your Guard, the Princes of Sicily, and of Naples, have felt the Power of your Eyes; if I am not deceived, their Amour will put you to ome
Trouble. Brother, aid Camilla to him, with a little Bluh, if my Eyes could revenge us of all the Deolation that the Sicilians have committed in our Territories, why are not you willing I hould employ them againt the Prince of Sicily? Ah! Siter, aid Amaldee to her, How zealous are you to take up a Quarrel, whoe Vengeance ought not to be your Province and in all Probability, How weakly would you defend your Heart againt an Enemy, whom your Eyes are willing to attach? I confes, replyed the Princes, hurryed away by her Paion, Frederick appears lovely to me, and if he was enible— Ah! it is too much interrupted, Amaldee, let us get out of the Hands and Dominions of a Prince, whoe Merit is fatal to the Liberty of a Princes, who is to command
elewhere. It is no longer time to think of that, aid he to him, all in Tears, I am no longer Mitris of my Heart, and all the Favour I demand of you, is, to prevent my becoming Princes of Barcelonna. Ah! Siter, aid he to her, your Reaon is aleep, when you ought to think of defending your elf; it is yet time enough, the firt Motions are eaiet to vanquih, Abence may ecure your Reitance, content your elf with the Delight of eeing the Power of your Charms, and do not employ them againt your elf. This was the Counel of a Prince, whoe Experience was but mall in Love. For, we cannot top there, we are willing to enjoy the Fruit of a Conquet, and to what Purpoe is being beloved, if we have not a Deign to love? Camilla was well acquainted with
thee Maxims, he was not ignorant of her Tendernes, and only aimed at being beloved, that he might not love in vain. How tender and moving an Idea did he repreent to her elf of the Sweets of a reciprocal Love! and notwithtanding the little Repoe that thee agreeable Thoughts afforded her, how beautiful did he appear the next Day to the amorous Leon! This Prince not knowing what to comprehend of Frederick's Dicoure, came to inform himelf of his Mitres, and to repair the Occaion he had failed of the Day before. Camilla had too tender Thoughts to keep up that haughty Air, which makes the boldet Lover tremble: there appeared o much Sweetnes in her fair Eyes, that the Prince imagined that it was a fit Occaion to declare himelf: he wavered
more than once to peak through the ineparable Repect of a great paion; and through the Addres of Camilla, who knowing his Thoughts, diverted the Converation of them with all the Liberty of a contented Mind. She propoed to him to go a walking, which he durt not refue; and Prince Amaldee, at his Siters Deire, kept them Company. They came to a place where was an admirable Eccho, and Amaldee prevailed with his Siter, to ing a Tune he had made ome time before; whereto, the Words were as follow.
div.l: nmov'd, I aw a thouand Charms each Day:
But when a Heart like ome young tender Deer,
Careles and wanton, here and there does play,
That it's in Danger, one has Caue to fear.
So oon as Love it's Innocence perceives,
He treight employs all his enticing Art;
Each Intant him ome new Advantage leaves,
And at the lat, it gives him all the Heart.
div.p: When he had done inging, he heard another Peron likewie exerciing his Voice, which was Frederick, who was entertaining his Melancholy; and without having heard Camilla, was inging thee words at ome ditance.
div.l: When that a Heart under fierce Flames does faint,
T'affect being gay and brisk, and mot at eae,
Is a evere, a hard, a ad Contraint;
But when with trict et Bonds, Love does it eize,
It's Tyranny is likewie to retrain
By oft Complaints to eae it's cruel Pain.
div.p:
Camilla imagined, that he had o great a Share in what he ung, as obliged her to make an Anwer; o that very eaonably remembring ome Veres that Prince Ardalin
had formerly learnt her, and which uting admirably well with the Subject, he ung them as they were couched, in thee Terms.
div.l: Though that a Heart is een all on a Fire,
And that it's ecret Martyrdom is ure,
There till remains to perfect the Deire,
The weet Delight, it to be beg'd to Cure;
Which, when deferred, who can, alas, endure!
div.p:
Amaldee did but too well know the Vivacity of this o jut Application which his Siter made, in Anwer to Frederick's Veres; and Prince Leon imagined, that he had made them at that very Intant; Frederick alone, undertood nothing of this Mytery;
he was o poeed with his Penivenes, that nothing but the Caue was capable of diverting it. They approached him by little and little, and the Prince of Majorca having ome Indulgence for his Siter, whom he aw was forced to love by her Star, was willing to render her an Office that he would have done himelf, if he had known what had paed in the Heart of Frederick; inomuch, that he dexterouly drew aide Leon, though with terrible Violences.

Camilla had immediately an agreeable Tranport to find her elf alone with the Prince of Sicily; but he made but ill Returns, and he maintained much better the Character of a Mitres, than he of a Gallant. His Eyes followed Amaldee, and purued him by languihing Looks, which endeavoured
to draw the Prince of Majorca to him Leon was ever cating his Eyes towards Camilla, who took little Notice of his amorous Actions: neither knew he what to think of Frederick's Procedure, and was upon the Point of preventing what he ought to have aid to her, and encourage by her Kindnes, that Lover whom he could only accue of too much Circumpection. Her Haughtines, whereof Women have little when they are in Love, would not have been ufficient to have made her keep Meaures; he would have poken, if Prince Leon had not had too much Tendernes for to uffer hers to take it's Coure. Being become knowing in a hort Time, he was eaily inclined to think that Love had a great hare in their mute Converation; and believing that he had but too long
permitted his Rival to enjoy what he imagined to merit, as much as he, his Return was omething precipitated. This Incivility did not at all amaze Amaldee, but Camilla did ufficiently let him know her Dipleaure, to hinder him another Time from uch Importunate Interruptions, if Lovers can be ever more circumpect.

Though Frederick was overjoyed at his being o happily freed from o perplexed an Encounter, yet he fell immediately into an other of no les Intricacy. Yolanda, as we have already aid, being concealed in Meina, gave him notice that ame Evening of her Arrival, conjuring him to meet her in an Arbour, which her Friend had judged proper for the Aignation. Frederick was obliged to go thither, and knowing the Afflictions of an ill-rewarded
Affection, he was not willing to be the Occaion of uffering them. Well, Prince, aid Yolanda to him, at his coming, are not you full of Acknowledgment for the Sentiments I have ever entertained of you, and of the Troubles your Abence has given me. Frederick by deceiving her agreeably, being willing to give a Looe to his own Paion, made Anwer, Yes, my dear Yolanda, I have been tormented ince your Abence, by all the Cruelties of Love; and I never knew what Grief was, till after I had been deprived of the Delight of eeing you. He was going to continue, when he heard at a little ditance the mot lamentable hriek that can be. Camilla, whom her ill Detiny had conducted jut to the Place of the Rendevouz, which was not far from her Apartment,
had heard the Princes's Voice, and dicovered a Rival, at a time when he was o tenderly poeed with the ole Idea of Frederick, he was not able to upport this Revere, and fell into a woon jut at the place from whence the Voice came: Frederick ran thither, and Yolanda withdrew, not being in a condition to give help to others, that might have hazarded her own Reputation, he only gave notice to her Friend of what had paed, who came thither in all hate, tho however too late. Berranger's Daughter had received, without knowing it, that aitance from the mot cruel of her Perecutors; he took Water from a Fountain that was hard by, and having prinkled ome of it upon her Face, he made her eaily come to her elf. Perhaps that the Delight which
her heart, tho in depair, felt at the approaches of the Peron who had rendred her enible, did contribute very much towards the making her recover the Ue of her Senes; he opened her Eyes, and eeing her elf in the hands of a Peron who caued all her trouble, Vexation eized her oul, and following her firt motion, he withdrew omething rudely, and got to her Apartment, without turning towards him, who had newly rendred her that good Office, Where Love is outraged, it often takes every thing for Affronts. In hort, the Princes, of Sicily being left alone, with her Mind full of its own Diquiets, he made but a Moments reflection upon all thee capricious Incidents, which he alo did with relation, that to her the like might happen, What a Night did Camilla
pas! all the torments of Jealouie preented themelves to her Imagination; and tho her Choller had no Object to fix it elf upon, he entertained a thouand Deigns, againt whomoever it was that uurped from her that Heart which he had thought her elf in poeion of; then repenting on a udden, he felt all thoe touching Motions that a generous and an afflicted Soul can be enible of, How? aid he, is my Affection les violent for being concealed? and ought it to be ill rewarded for being produced omething later than that, which my Ungrateful is o fond of? Mad that I am, added he, Shall I diturb the Peace of two Lovers, whom Heaven had united before I dream'd of being engag'd? No, let us leave them to enjoy all thoe Delights which I
had vainly figured to my elf, and let us not one moment divert them through the compaion of Mieries that I have drawn upon my elf by having been too credulous. All thee doleful thoughts kept her company as long as the Night continued; Day appeared before that her Mind could find a moment of Repoe. Amaldee came, as he often did, to ee her in her Chamber, and he having been the innocent caue of her Tears, at the ight of him he could not forbear redoubling them. Ah! why have you educed me by the deceiving Appearance of being beloved by the Prince of Sicily? Why, by making me apprehenive of his Tendernes, hould you render it o dangerous to me? Ah! continued he, eeing he made no Anwer, Why did you
not keep that Silence that would have pared me o many Tears? Why did you pronounce that fatal Word by it's enchanting Sweetnes? —Heaven is my Witnes, interrupted Amaldee, that my Intention was to hinder you from loving by—Alas! interrupted Camilla, hatily, was that the way to hinder me from loving, by telling me that I was beloved? Why did you not rather tell me, as was true, that he languihes for another? It would have made me igh; but I hould at leat have avoided the mortal Troubles that devour me. She thereupon related to him all that he had hear'd, exagerating the thing as much as her Paion could inpire her, and endeavouring to exhale her Grief in Reproaches, he was not able to make an End. When Perons are omething recovered from their
firt Tranports, they aim at being Eloquent, that they may at leat make others hare with them in their Misfortunes. But Amaldee, judging that he wanted Repoe, left it her in ome kind, by leaving her Chamber, for he remained as motion-les after his departure, and found her elf in that condition wherein we have already repreented the Princes of Sicily, who by lying under the heaviet Oppreions, enjoyed ome kind of Tranquillity, and ome time after he fell very dangerouly ill.

In the mean while, Prince Ardalin having got ome intelligence of his Bride's being cat away upon the Coat of Sicily, he came thither incognito to inform himelf of the truth. The Shipwrack of his Mitris had o dejected and penetrated him with o lively a
grief, that he was not to be known. The firt Object that offered it elf to his Eyes was Amaldee, who was thinking of the means to free his Siter out of the Abys of Depair wherein he aw her plunged. The Prince of Majorca was at firt urprized to ee Ardalin in the Territories of Sicily, and was hardly able to recover from it, by reaon of the change that Affliction had wrought in his Countenance, inomuch that he only anwered with a igh, when Ardalin made enquiry after Camilla. This igh cot the Prince of Barcelonna many more. He no longer doubted, but that his Princes had been wallowed up by the Waves, and being pierced to the quick by o fatal a Thought; Speak, aid he, Prince, peak, and no longer conceal from me a los which I
ought not to urvive. Amaldee knowing that an Infidelity is the mot afflicting thing that can be told a Lover, was in no hate to undeceive him; but being at length preed to make Anwer, he lives, aid he to him, but ask me nothing more concerning her, and would to Heaven you may never be informed of the ret. Thee Words, though the latter part of them were capable of giving terrible Supicions, failed not to calm the Soul of Ardalin; and not penetrating the Motive of that Sadnes, he upended his own, upon learning that he hould again ee Camilla; and being recovered from the Fright he had been in for her Life, all the ret eemed weet and eaie. Amaldee acquainted him in few Words, with all that had happened to them, except what he ought never
to have known. He gave him notice not to dicover them, and as for himelf, having but a mall Train, he would hardly be known for the Prince of Barcelonna. They came at length, to the Palace where the whole Dicoure was of Camilla's Sicknes: That Princes, after having been brought out of a Lethargy, had made uch powerful Efforts to cure her Heart, that her Body had fallen under the weight of them. She was taken with o violent a Fever, that from the Beginning, they were apprehenive of the Iue: However, Ardalin went with Amaldee to Camilla's Apartment. How great was the Atonihment of the Princes, at that unexpected Sight! The Remore of having neglected a Huband who left all to come and eek her, the Shame of having betrayed him for a
Peron, who triumphed, perhaps, in her Sufferings, and may be boated of them to her Rival, put her into a trange Confuion. As Amaldee would have prepared her for Ardalin's Arrival, whom he had but too well known, he interrupted him; and addreing her Speech to the Count of Barcelonna, From whence come you, Prince, aid he to him, and what makes you take uch Care of a Wretch, whom Heaven has but too much abandoned? Ah! Madam, aid that Prince to her, it is too jut to let o extraordinary a Peron languih any longer, you may hope all manner of Happines from it's Jutice, and thereupon, Leon entred the Room, who came to inform himelf of the Princees Health: his Preence, which at other times he thought a Trouble, was pleaing in this Occaion,
ince it interrupted a Converation that made her very uneaie. She gave her Brother to undertand by a Sign, that he hould take it for a Favour to be left alone; which Prince Leon comprehending, he went firt away, without making any other Reflection than what his Mitries Sicknes in • ued, which poeed all his Thoughts. Amaldee dragg'd likewie away the Prince of Barcelonna, who without knowing all his Misfortunes, had however enough to put an end to his Days. Leon was no les to be pityed than Ardalin; Camilla, during the time her Fever lated, could hardly uffer that he hould come to inform himelf of the Condition he was in, that he might not be obliged to receive any Viits, nor to ee him whom he had but too much een for her Repoe; inomuch,
that Frederick's Abence being as dangerous a Misfortune as all thoe he already lay under, it brought her almot to the lat Gap. The Princes of Sicily was likewie languihing, by Reaon of Amaldee's Affliction, in whom he could not uffer that Sadnes for any other than her elf. In hort, there was nothing but Lamentation in Sicily; and one would have aid, that Love revenged himelf on the Princees Diguie: But Camilla was yet much more to be pityed, the frequent fainting Fits that her too much oppreed Heart did bring her in, made her imagine, that he hould quickly find a favourable Death.

One day, after coming out of a cold Sweat, which he believed the Fore-runner of her End, he ent for her Brother, and her Huband, and having made them it
on her Bed-ide, Prince, aid he, looking upon Ardalin, it is no longer time to diguie any thing, I will pare you the Regret that you would have for the Los of me, by defacing my elf out of your Memory, too happy! if the Confeion of my Weaknees do not render it odious to you. I am no longer that evere Camilla who made a Scruple of proceeding farther than Eteem for a Prince, who was to have been her Huband. I have felt the mot lively Sentiments of Love, if I may o ay, for an other than your elf, but Care has been taken to revenge you on my Ingratitude, by having my Affection depied. Farewel, aid he to him, forget me if you can, and pardon me my Errors. I pardon you them, Divine Princes, aid Ardalin, I know the Fatality of the Inclination,
which forces us to love, but I cannot pardon my elf for not having known how to gain your Affection; my Heart is without doubt, irritated, to find that you refue it that Tendernes which you are capable of; but it is againt my elf, and I alone ought to expiate the Crime of not having been able to pleae you. At this ad Thought he fainted away, and lot with all his Senes, that of the Infidelity of his Mitris; but they brought him to himelf by the help of Remedies, which made him enjoy till, for ome Moments, all the Malignity of his Fate, The Alarums he had had for Camilla's Life, whom he had believed to have been wallowed up by the Waves, and the Certainty of her Change, penetrated him with o lively a Grief, that it is no Wonder, if he fell under the
weight of it in that o fatal Moment, and the Violence of the Motions of his Soul was o great, that the Wound he had received did re-open in that Intant: he did not perceive that his Spirits diipated; and indeed, he was wounded in a more enible part. Ah! Princes, aid he to her, I am enible, that your Indifference does abridge a Life that I had devoted to you, and which has not been o happy as to pleae you: I dye; and may it pleae the Cruelty of Love to content it elf with my Life, and not extend it's Vengeance upon the Days of o beautiful a Princes. It is ufficient, that I acrifice mine to it, which was wholly yours; but let at leat, my lat Sigh draw ome from you, at leat, let them be out of Pity, and do not refue them to a Lover who ready to expire, out of
Tendernes, demands of you nothing ele: after he had poken thee Words, a mortal Languihing urpried him; his Eyes fixed upon Camilla, hewed till, by their dying Looks, all the Fervency imaginable, and caued a Torrent of Tears to guh out from thoe of that deolate Princes. Amaldee endeavoured to uccour Ardalin, and to recal his Spirits which had entirely abandoned him. The Rumour of all that paed was quickly pread about; one of the Princees Maids could not forbear blaming Frederick openly; and he himelf came thither as well as others, and mixing his particular Misfortunes with thoe of the publick, he was willing to try, if he could at the ame Time change the Face of things. Camilla eeing the Author of o many Mieries, was not
able to upport the Sight of him, and turned her elf on the other ide. Frederick oberving that Action, came and cat himelf at her Feet, and following his natural Propenity, made her remark o much Paion in his Eyes, that Camilla, notwithtanding her Dejection, did quickly perceive it. What would you have, Prince, aid he to him with a low Voice? Ah! Madam, how late is it to declare my elf, aid the tender Frederick to her; I love, but alas! I could never have reolved to have let you know it till this Extremity. Ah! Prince, aid he to him, do not contrain your elf; the too certain Knowledge I have of the Sentiments you have for an other, has brought me into this Condition; but I loe it with my Life. Ah! Madam, cryed Frederick, I attet Heaven, that I have
no Sentiments prejudicial to what I owe you, and you will one day ee that I am only unhappy. Thee Words, which o eaily ininuated themelves into her Soul, made her igh; and thinking of what he owed the Prince of Barcelonna, withdraw, aid he to him, with ome Difficulty, withdraw, and leave me to die les criminal, if I cannot die altogether innocent.

In the mean while, Ardalin being come again to himelf, and taking a new Vigour from the Sight of the Prince of Sicily, whom he then knew for his Rival, he ued all his Efforts to peak, but not being able to do o, he melted the Hearts of all thoe who aw him. His Gapings re-doubling, the Company perceived that he was ready to breath his lat; and having made them comprehend by
mot moving Demontrations imaginable, that he had a Deire to approach the Princes, they brought him to her Bed-ide: whereupon, his Forces returned to him when he was upon the Point of loing them for ever; and looking upon Frederick and Camilla, live, aid he to them, happy Lovers, o beautiful a Princes could only be born for o accomplihed a Prince. I am not at all ahamed to yield to a Rival, who excells me by o many Advantages, and whom I can only urpas by my Tendernes. At thee Words, having fixed his Mouth upon Camilla's Hands, he eemed ineparable from that afflicted Peron, and his Soul being detained by that Pleaure, had all the Difficulty imaginable to fly away. Thus Love terminated the Days of a Prince, who by the Greatnes of
his Paion ought to have been reerved for a better Detiny: So ad a Spectacle put all the Aitants into a Conternation, and their gloomy Silence was only interrupted by the lamentable Cries of Camilla; they caued his Corps to be removed, who occaioned all this Sadnes: he eemed till animated by his Love and his greedy Looks, which appeared not altogether extinguihed, eemed as if they could never be atiated with eeing what he had o much loved.

During all this Confuion, they had forgot to diemble; Ardalin's Attendants Train dicovered him by their Regrets for the Prince of Barcelonna; and Amaldee and Camilla were likewie known to be the Children of King Berranger, though they did not expect to be dicovered. They
could not have choen a more favourable Moment; for, Peoples Minds were altogether dipoed to Pity, there was no Room for Hatred: and the King continued to them the ame Kindnes he had already afforded them, as he only conidered them by themelves; he did not change the Sentiments he had of them, though they had changed their Names as to him. But, the Princes of Sicily was over-joyed to hear that Amaldee and Camilla were only Brother and Siter, and filling her Soul with the oft Motions which ucceeded in the place of the cruel Supicions that had agitated her, her Tendernes was thereby coniderably augmented. If he found in him the Son of Menfroy's Enemy, a Prince for whom he was forced to that o ingular Diguie, in hort, one who ought never to
wear the Crown of Sicily, he found in Recompence, a Prince full of Charms, a Prince who might be engaged in her Favour; he no longer found a Rival; and that Obtacle being removed, did ufficiently make amends for all that might be contrary to her: Thus being in Repoe, as to her Lover, he was no longer diquieted about obtaining him for her Husband. Ardalin's Body was ent back to Barcelonna, with all the Magnificence that became him and Menfroy: And a Poet made his Epitaph; which is as follows.
div.l: Within this Tomb Fidelity is laid,
With the kind Lover who Nature's Debt hath paid;
Henceforth, like him few Lovers will be een,
And, in my mind, Heaven has too cruel been,
Who dy'd for Love, deerv'd here to have tai'd.
div.p:
Nothing could recover Camilla; and though Remedies had removed her Fever, yet her Affliction was as bad as all Dieaes. Leon having been Witnes of all that had paed between Camilla and Frederick, all the aurances he receiv'd from this Prince were not capable of atisfying him. He could in no wie comprehend the important Mytery he was to expect the iue of. Beides, this Princes was in love with another, which was ufficient to deprive him of all Repoe. Amaldee, whoe Heart was free from any Impreion, was continually repaing in his memory the Events that had newly happened. All
his mind was full of the hade of Ardalin, and all his Actions hew'd him very Melancholy. As he often did walk all alone, the Princes of Sicily did the ame through another motive, inomuch that they often met, but never joyned company; the Princes's Paion rendring her fearful, made her avoid the Peron whom her Heart ought with too much eagernes, and he either took no notice of it, or was not very earnet to ask her the reaon. However, one day, as Frederick was paing by him, and pretending not to ee him; Lovers are very alvage, aid Amaldee to him laughing, and I think my elf very happy in having my heart of a more obdurate temper than yours; after what I know of Love, I would not for any thing make the Experience of it, but
will neglect, as much as poible, thoe Beauties who excite o intire an application; and ince we ought to acrifice all our thoughts to what we love, I am reolved never to love any thing. The Princes, who was trangely afflicted with this Dicoure, made him however an anwer with omething a cornful tone; Well, keep to that indifference you find o very charming. She had not the power to ay any thing more, but went away very much dipleaed. And Amaldee eeing Frederick depart after that manner, was omething diatisfied; and, not believing he had offended him, he made Reflection upon all his reerved and unhandome Procedure, and found in his way of living with him, omething very particular, which he could only take for the Effect of ome natural
Antipathy. He admired how a Peron could love the Siter, whoe Brother he o much hated, but reolved, however, to erve him both in his Hatred and his Amour. He wrote to the King his Father, and endeavouring to melt him by the good Offices that had been done them, he propoed to him a Match between Camilla and Frederick, aying, that it eemed as if Heaven had already aembled their Hearts for the uniting their Families for ever, and adding, that Menfroy would not oppoe it; that the Kindnes he had for his Son, would make him pas over all manner of Interets; that this King was of a generous Nature; and that provided he would make the leat Advance towards an Accommodation, a Peace would quickly be concluded. This Letter had not
all the Succes it ought to have had, as will be made appear in the Sequel.

In the mean time, Amaldee not being capable of hating Frederick, avoided him however, for fear his Preence hould prove troubleome. Some Days after the Converation that had eparated them, they met in uch another Conjuncture; it was nice, Amaldee tept back, and Frederick ighed to ee that Amaldee retired firt; a Sigh is not to be interpreted, I hate you; however, that Sigh made the Prince of Majorca think o: But, Frederick in his Turn, could not comprehend the Caue why he hould o hun his Company; thus they were both deceived by very contrary Reaons. If Amaldee's Indifference made him take for Hatred what was nothing les, the Tendernes
of the Princes of Sicily, who eaily believed what he apprehended, made her likewie take for Contempt, what was very far from it; for, though he did not appear under the Figure of a Lover, that did not hinder her from being o; and if Neglect ought not to have directly offended her Paion, yet he failed not to be wounded by the Effects, which the Intention did not ufficiently jutifie with her. Alas! aid that Princes, Why does he not find himelf forced to love me, though his Reaon does oppoe it? I find, I love him without the Conent of mine; but he is far from being under uch Circumtances; Why has not he more penetrating Eyes, and why cannot he ditinguih the Heart of a Mitris under the Figure of a Lover? The languihing of my Eyes, ought, methinks, to have
unravelled to him this Mitery, but his were not willing to ee it, or if they did, they have depied the Dicovery. The Figure of Frederick, is it o contemptible, that it has not yet been capable of making a Friend of Amaldee, ince the Princes of Sicily dares not make him her Lover? And not daring to entertain any hopes for her elf, mut he needs be reduced to wih ome Repects for Frederick, whom Amaldee takes o much care to avoid. As Love is addicted to making Veres, and that Poetry entertains and charms our Amorous Thoughts, he fell to making an Elegy, which occaion'd many other Diorders. The Princes of Majorca began to leave her Chamber, and Frederick, who through the Conformity of their Detiny, and the reemblance he had with Amaldee, afforded
her a great deal of Complaiance, accompanied her the firt day he went abroad, after a very melting Converation. Camilla, eeing this Prince carry himelf with o much kindnes, began to forget the los of Ardalin, inomuch that having thought ome moments, he asked him for his Table-book, wherein he wrote thee following Veres, he had newly made.

q.l: In vain one lately dead my Heart did claim,
And yet another with Love it now has fill'd,
But when with him for whom our Breat does flame,
We traight forget whom Cruelty has kill'd.

div.p:
This was omething to inult the Memory of Ardalin, but the leat reaonable Sentiments are the mot meritorious in Love; Frederick
anwered them at that intant by the four following, whoe Equivocation failed not to be interpreted by Camilla according as he deigned.
div.l: You igh, alas! but reging is my mart,
My Soul being charm'd, has more of me requir'd,
You have the Features of what wounds my Heart,
But what is that to One, like me, inpir'd?
div.p:
The Princes miled at this anwer, and eem'd very well atisfied, but Frederick taking out his Table-book, drew out with it, and let fall a Paper, which was preently taken up by the curious Camilla, without Frederick's knowledge: She tay'd till ome moments with him, which
eem'd but too long to her impatience; inomuch that having taken a handome pretext to leave him, he went to her Chamber to read the Paper he had taken up. You may judge of her Thoughts at the perual of this Elegy.

div.head: AN ELEGY.
div.l: HOW! treacherous Heart, art thou to Love inclin'd?
I feel, alas! I know not what that's kind.
Thou, who in ecret didt all Love depie,
And for Tranquillity thy elf didt prize;
Thou now do't toop, who haughty us'd to be,
And yield't to pains, none e're inpir'd like thee.
Th' Attack that's made on thee by thouand Charms,
Inflames thy Coldnes, and thy Strength diarms.
In my Indifference Deigns I form'd,
Of braving Love, tho with all's Force he torm'd;
My elf did flatter from common Weaknes free,
This Heart well aided mine would ever be:
Or if a lovely Object eiz'd my Soul,
My Senes abence would urprie controul.
All charming Sports I thought I would avoid,
Or if I lov'd, 't hould be as if I toy'd:
My Honour thus I'de raie to th' high't degree,
My elf I'de punih for enibility,
Such were the Projects of my Soul when free.
All thee I quitted, though they did abound,
When Love his moment, 's cruel moment found.
Can we what charms s fly? a hope mot vain,
Can we that Object fly, the Heart does chain?
And all our Senes joyntly with us betray'd,
Are they not charm'd, and in a Tranport laid?
My haughtines refue thy ueles aid,
But don't with Weaknes my poor Soul upbraid.
Tyrannick Reaon do not come and tear
A Heart, that Scorns have almot made depair:
And which, ubdu'd to Laws of hard Contraint,
Shuts Eyes to Tears, and Mouth to all Complaint.
Why did't thou tray in my mot preing need?
Why for one moment did't upend thy heed?
Love did that fatal intant take thy place,
Expect not e're thy rigour can him chace:
In vain its Calm and Peace thou would't retore,
Since thou once left it, thou can't return no more.
Begone, begone, thy Reign does here expire,
I hear no Counels, but what Love inpire.
The Charms of my new Fancy I purue,
Heav'ns! that in loving, I'm belov'd were true!
I mut, alas! my Martyrdom declare,
To love I fear not, but to tell't I fear.
I igh and tremble, when I hould it impart,
My Tongue is fearful, but not at all my Heart.
Love, make me bold, thou, who hat made me kind,
And to dear A.—for me declare my Mind,
Whoe Heart, tho now exempt from Pain and Care,
In learning mine may likewie have its hare.

div.p:
Spight eized her Soul at the reading of this; and looking upon Frederick, who was jut come in to entertain her with a thouand kind things, as the mot treacherous of all men; her Jealouie produced, in that Intant, a quite contrary Effect from what the former had done; it retored her all her Spirits through the Ardour of Revenge. However, he was in a very great Perplexity, the Idea of a Beauty, who had deprived her of Frederick's Heart, did put her to a terrible Torture;
and thinking to hate Frederick, he did not perceive that he hated all the Ladies of the Court, for fear of not hating her, who put her to that Torment. There was not one that did not give her a ecret Pain; he deired and feared at the ame time to find what he ought; and hewing the Elegy to all the Ladies, confes, aid he to them, after a rallying manner, confes that you are very happy in having inpired uch delicate Sentiments in o incere a Prince as Frederick: Then thinking to read in their Eyes what they had in their Souls, he examined them with the mot uneaie Attention in the World. Several read the Elegy, without finding themelves concerned therein; they had all been o ready to receive Frederick's Flames, that not one of them could make
the Application to her elf of the Complaints it contained. Camilla began to breath again, and recovered by Degrees from the Apprehenions he had had. When the Lord High Admiral's Wife, taking the Elegy with ome Didain, began firt to mile, then a Bluh, which came into her Face, giving Camilla to undertand, that he ought to fix her Jealouie upon her; Madam, aid he to her, your diguting Haughtines for any other Lover, gives you a Prince wearied with Sighs; but have a Care, if I am not deceived, your Ladihip will not long maintain that Character; for, I have oberved in your firt Motions, omething o far from Cruelty, that if the Sequel be anwerable to this Beginning, I am very much afraid, that that Severity, which you have had during Frederick's
Indifference, will end with it: However, follow my Counel, continue your Severity, if you are deirous that a Paion hould lat which it has produced. You are in the right, aid the Admiral's Lady to her, riing to be gone: The Princes was tung to the Quick, both at the Anwer, and her uncivil Departure. They all retired thereupon, every one reaoning after their own manner, upon the capricious Choice of Frederick. Yolanda was quickly informed hereof, by the means of her Friend; and, by the order he had to return to Court, her Mother-in-Law having made Reflection upon the Elegy, found that it admirably well uted with her Circumtances. The little Regard he had had for a Prince her Lover, could only pas with her for Contempts; o much Management
on his part, could only be for a Woman, who had too much out-raged him to love her without Shame; and what confirmed this, was the Name of Amaldee, which the Princes durt not write at length; which being very like her own, (he being called Amedee) did fully confirm her in that Opinion. Any other than one concerned, would never have unravelled that trembling and ambiguous Character; but, what does not Love do when it goes about it? Inomuch, that being aured of that Heart which Yolanda had vainly imagined that he poeed, he was very willing to have her for a Witnes of her Happines. The Vexation of a Rival is a great Satisfaction to a Lover, who triumphs, with great Delight, over one he had had any Apprehenions of. What a Diappointment
to Yolanda, to return to Court for the Infidelity of a Prince, when her too great Facility had drove her from thence; but he mut obey, which he the more willingly did, that he might clear a Supicion that could hardly enter into her Mind. She thought her Mother-in-Law very unfit to uurp a Heart which Camilla had not been able to make a Conquet of; for, her Friend had heard one ay, that Frederick had aured, that Camilla was not the Peron whom he mot paionately loved; but, that there was another, for whom he hould igh as long as he lived. Yolanda had ome Reaon to believe the Contancy of the Prince herein, being deceived by the Relation that thee Words had, with the good Opinion he had of her elf touching Frederick. In hort, being returned to her Mother-in-Law,
he found her diarmed of that evere and alvage Air, which Women quickly lay aide, when they have a Lover who pleaes them; he took upon her the Air gallant, and reproaching her elf in ecret, with having lot by her little Undertanding in Love, thoe Moments which he might have pent with great Delight, had he known Frederick's Inclination; he had a Mind to recall them, and was contriving how to embolden him whom he had rendred fearful by her too great Severity, and thought good to open the way her elf to his Puruit. Knowing that he often walked all alone, he deigned to meet him in his Paage, which he accordingly performed, the ame Day. Frederick had tol'n from the Crowd, and leaning upon one of his Hands, let ome
Tears tricle down his Cheeks, which the amorous Sicilian thought worthy of her Pity; he approached him oftly, and told him, bluhing, alas! Prince, is there no way to put an end to Sufferings which afflict all the Court; Joy dares no longer appear there, ince you have banihed it from your elf: All our Ladies are penetrated with the Languihing which opprees their Prince. That Languihing, anwered he omething indifferently, ought not in any wie to concern all the Ladies you reproach me with, ince the only Peron whom it ought to move with Pity,—Proceed Prince, aid he to him, eeing that he topped there; I very well undertand, that ome too evere fair one does make you, fearful of ill Succes in a Paion that
mut needs, however, be uccesful; But, Why do not you peak? There is not a Beauty how haughty oever he may be, but would willingly hare with you in all the Sentiments you entertain of her. But, Frederick made her no Reply, and after having returned everal Times to the Charge, eeing he made no Progres, and Frederick irritating her by his too great Reervednes, he quitted him with ome kind of Dipleaure.
div.trailer: The End of the Firt Part.

div.p: THE FEMALE PRINCE; OR, FREDERICK OF SICILY.
PART II.
LONDON, Printed for Hen. Rodes, next door to the Bear Tavern in Fleet-treet, near Fleet-Bridge, 1682.

div.head: THE FEMALE PRINCE; OR, FREDERICK OF SICILY.
PART II.
div.p:
IN the mean time, the Truce was upon the point of being at an end, Berranger had taken very ill the Propoitions of Amaldee, and the Commendations he had given of Menfroy, he commanded him to return home with all peed, to how if the Prince of Majorca ought to peak like
the Son of the King of Sicily. This Prince, well fore-eeing after what manner he hould be treated by his Father, would not however be diobedient, and beeeched Menfroy to give him the liberty to leave his Dominions, which was granted him, with the ame facility that he was uffered to come into them. They embraced very affectionately, being charmed with one another's Virtue From thence Amaldee went to Frederick's Apartment, being to take his leave of him; tho he had ent to inquire, if his Viit would not prove importunate, and that he was prepared to receive it, yet he was however diordered at his arrival. Be pleaed to give me leave, aid Amaldee to him, to render you Thanks for all Your Civilities, which I have very well ditinguihed, notwithtanding what
a Sentiment of Hatred may inpire you with againt a Prince, whom his misfortune has borne your Enemy. At thee words the Princes was extremely troubled; he would have tifled ome ighs, but that he found impoible, and her Confuion was thereby o much the more augmented. Amaldee not knowing what to think of this, asked her the caue of her Diorder; this put her quite out of Countenance, and though the Habit he wore did ecure her from the upicions that might have been had of the truth, it was ufficient to be culpable in her elf, to believe he appeared o to others. For though he had ome thoughts of unbooming her elf, that Deign did not continue long, and her Severity did hinder her from putting it in execution. Leave me, Prince, aid he adly to
him, and, if poible, give no credit to what you ee. This was certainly a great Mitery to him, and he went and related to his Siter all that had paed between them. She thought he comprehended it better than he did, and imagined that it might be the Remore of having betrayed the Siter, whoe Brother treated him with that Civility, and that a return without doubt would follow it. This was ufficient to overturn all that had been projected againt him, and thereupon he wrote him a Letter, that might do more than re-aure him. The Princes of Sicily received it, after having undergone terrible Conflicts, having accued her elf of weaknes in not having known how to undeceive the Prince of the averion he was in no wie capable to entertain of him, for this was what
he mot apprehended he would believe. It is impoible for a Peron in Love to leave the Party beloved in a Belief of being hated. She had judged very well after her firt Motion, that he would know nothing more; and reolved, at all Adventures, to remove the Impreion of what might prepoes him againt her, and be injurious to what he might perhaps one day know of the Coure of her Inclinations. Remaining fix'd in this Deign, he enjoyed ome Repoe, and read the Letter that was brought her from Camilla, which was conceived in thee Terms.

body.head: To the Prince of Sicily.
body.p:
IT is very difficult for People to keep up their Reentments, when they have once lot their Hearts; and ince you have made a Conquet
of mine, can it have any Motions to your Diadvantage? I am however very much ahamed that I have not been able to reit either your feigned Paion, or your real Neglect. I ought, at leat, to have given them the ame Detiny; But, alas! it lay not in my Power. I hould find it much more eaie, to be inenible to your Ingratitude than to all that peaks in your Favour, notwithtanding I have found uch ill Returns. Love me, or love me not; you may do either, without making me change my Sentiments: But, will you miue this Power? And will you leave a Princes to love alone, when you would find it very delightful to love reciprocally? But, I mut explain my elf further with you; to which Purpoe, I deire you would meet me in the great Alley that leads to the Oval.

div.p: Camilla did not expect that her Letter hould have proved o kind, but when a Woman is writing to her Lover, it is Love that conducts the Pen; and he cannot oppoe the rapidity with which it paints what the Heart inpires and dictates. Frederick was making ome Reflections upon this Letter, when another was brought him, and the Peron who delivered it vanihed at the ame intant, without expecting any Anwer; but it came from the Admiral's Lady, and he found therein thee words.

body.head: To the Prince of Sicily.
body.p:
WHY do you continue obtinate, to conceal what other Lovers are earnet to make known? What do you pretend to do, either love me not, or tell me
that you do. A Paion is ever languihing, as long as it is retrained by a faint and gloomy fear, which you perhaps take for Repect. But you are therein deceived, Repect is les alvage, He peaks, and then he is reerved, but till he has poken: he begins what finihes of it elf, and how great a pleaure is it for him that loves, to have it thought o! and for her who is beloved to think it likewie, and to divine the ret of what has been told her by halfs! If You love only me, You will eaily believe that it is only I who write to You. However, for the greater urety, meet me in the great Alley that leads to the Oval, where You may explain, and I hear what You have to ay.

div.p:
This Letter, though he knew not the hand, would have diverted Frederick at another time, if
the Tendernes which poeed him had not given him Motions very oppoite to Joy. He was admiring the Capriciounes of Love in thee two Letters, when a third was brought him, which he read with ome Precipitation and found therein.

body.head: To the Prince of Sicily.
body.p:
IT is in vain that Endeavours are ued to alarum me about your Contancy; my Heart tells me that you are faithful, which is ufficient to peruade me you are o; I judge of yours by my own: Our Hearts were ingaged in one Moment, and ought never to be diingaged, but at the ame time. Mine is faithful to You, Prince, and cannot be any other perons than yours, which is enough to make me warrant, that yours is wholly mine: neither is it to clear any Supicion, that I deire
you to meet me in the grat Alley near the Oval, it is only to aure you, that you have never yet given me any Jealouie. All that I hereby aim, is only that we may mingle our Sighs. Alas! we have ighed o long a part, that it is fit we hould igh for one Moment together.

div.p:
Frederick did very much upect, that this Letter came from Yolanda; he imagined that Detiny conducted him to the unravelling of o many Adventures; he fancyed that thee three Mitries meeting at the ame Randezvouz, would free him by an Appearance of Treachery, from all the real Importunities they had plyed him with: Inomuch, that decending into the Alley, he had hardly the Leiure to walk there a Moment, before he aw them all three a coming. He thought it trange to ee them together: but the thing
happened in this manner; Yolanda having placed her elf at a Window which looked out upon the way that was to be taken to go to the Alley, waited therefor Frederick's Arrival; and having een him pas, and immediately after him, a Woman, who walking with trembling Steps, took the ame way; he reolved to prevent her enjoying a Converation with Frederick, which he had been too long contriving it to leave it to others: he run thither with uch an earnetnes, that it was taken notice of by her Mother-in-Law, who had too great an Interet in her Conduct not to follow her. Where are you going, aid he to her? I ee a certain Emotion in your Countenance, that would make me upect that ome amorous Intrigue had brought you hither, if I knew not that after the Princes
o freh Infidelity, you could not be capable of a new Engagement. And I, Madam, anwered he, with a malicious Smile, I hould believe that you upected me through ome intereed Motion, if I aw not the Princes, whom you have more Reaon to fear than me. At that Word, all Reply ceaed, and they walked inenibly after Camilla, whom they overtook before he had entred the Alley; inomuch that being all three animated with the ame Spirit of Jealouie, they returned into an other, and never parted till they had een the Prince, who, weary with waiting for them, was gone, after he had een them take another way, and thought his Intrigues at an end, without himelf being any ways concerned. He fancyed, that their haughty Humors had hindred them from giving either's Rival the leat Occaion
of upecting their Deign or that the Severity of Amedee whoe Paion he had not yet taken notice of, had retrained them; in hort, not knowing to whom he was indebted for his good Luck, he reolved to take Advantage of it, and never to be with them alone, but even to avoid the Companies of all Women, that he might not be troubled with any more of their amorous Importunities: however, he was mitaken in his Conjectures, as thoe three Mitrees had been in thinking to deceive each other. As each of them had pretended not to have een the Prince, they all imagined in particular, that the Randezvouz had been only for them; and all of them applauding Frederick's Fidelity, and their Addres in concealing what they thought thereof, o that there paed a very gallant
Converation between them, and they parted with great Civilities. Camilla was the mot penive, as indeed he had the mot Reaon to be o; and that Occaion being lot, was hardly to be recovered. Her Brother was to depart the next day, he mut either go with him, or expoe her elf to her Fathers Rage, or to the Slights of her Lover, which was les eaie for her to upport. But, Love till wrought in her Favour; for, the Princes of Sicily, as we have aid, who was willing to repair all the Incivilities he had done to him whom he o tenderly loved, went to take her Leave of him; but he eaily perceived, by the Trouble he was in at her firt coming into his Preence, that it would be difficult for her to execute the Deigns he had laid in his Abence. The firt Civilities
being over, which he acquitted herelf of, with Gallantry enough, he was to proceed to omething of more Concern, which perhaps he would have but very ill performed: he already trembled, the Fear of aying too much or too little detained her for ome time in Silence, which was only ended by the coming in of Camilla, which both rejoyced and dipleaed her, eeing that deferred, which he would willingly have aid, and which he o much apprehended to ay. Camilla had the ame Sentiments, and perhaps they would not have poken, if Amaldee had not opened the Converation. Prince, aid he to Frederick, You ee a Princes allarm'd at the Vage he hall receive from an irritated Father. Ah! aid Camilla interrupting him, I have but too well merited his Dipleaure not to undergo the Effects
of it with Reignation. The King is very unhappy, aid Frederick to her, to ee himelf refued, even in the Azyls that he is deirous to afford you I know how much I am indebted to the King, aid he to him; but, the Prince of Sicily would do too great a penance, hould he ee inceantly the Object of his Hatred. Ah, Madam! interrupted Frederick, What a Monter would the Prince of Sicily be! Ah! aid Camilla, interrupting him again, it was no mall Effect of Hatred, that of pretending to love me for the depriving me of a Happines, whoe leat Idea was ufficient to urprie me: See, aid he to him, hewing him the Elegy, What a Delicacy for a Prince, whoe Flames are kindled by Severities, and how does Love over-turn the Order of all our Inclinations! It is this ame Prince who is to this point o tender and ubmiive!
In what Confuion was Frederick! His Paion was o naturally painted in thoe Veres, the Character of them was o tender, that Amaldee was very much moved; he was ome time without having the Power to jutifie himelf of a thing too true, but at length made ue of the Ambiguity for his Plea in that Occaion. Madam, aid he, addreing himelf to Camilla, I vow to you, once again, that all that I love is here. Say no more, interrupted Camilla, not doubting but that it was of her, he poke, How weet do I find thee Obcurities! After having imagined to have had o clear a Propect of my Mifortune, leave me in my Error, if you cannot draw me out of it, but at the Expence of that Affection which I o paionately purue. After which he quickly agreed to tay in Sicily, fearing, with jut Reaon, the
Dipleaure of Berranger, who had learn'd, with Indignation, the Kindnes he had for the Prince of Sicily; but, this was not enough, Frederick had yet aid nothing in his own Behalf, o that aluting Amaldee, he looked upon him very tenderly, And you, Prince, aid he to him, Will you till believe that I hate you? I know not, aid Amaldee to him likewie very tenderly, All that I can ay is that my Regret is extream to leave you in a time you are willing I hould believe you do not. They were not able to ay any thing more, their Tears trickled down reciprocally; and without doubt, the Prince of Majorca
felt that, I know not what, which Frederick found trange he had not yet been enible of. The Day after, he was to take his publick Leave of the King, all the Court was aembled, and Menfroy did
hew the great Eteem he had for the Prince of Majorca, by all the Carees he made him, and embraced him once again; after which, Amaldee made up to embrace Frederick, who retired ome Paces; but the King taking notice of that Action, made him a Sign not to dicover himelf, but to embrace the Prince: whereupon, a great Bluh mounted into his Face, and the Prince, when a repectuous Sentiment did already retrain, did advance without trembling; and if notice had been taken of that diorder, it would have been without doubt urprizing. After this, Amaldee returned immediately unto the King his Fathers Dominions, with all the Violence of a Man, who finds himelf drawn elewhere without knowing what it was that did o. He aw the King, who according to his Expectations, received
him like a diobedient Son, and who fell into a trange Paion againt Camilla, accuing her of Treaon, and vowing that he would go and drag her from the Arms of the triumphing Frederick. Alas! How little did he merit that Title, and under what Affliction did he lie, through the Abence of Amaldee. This lat Misfortune eemed to him inupportable; he fell ick of a lingring Fever, which heltred him from the Puruits of Yolanda and the Admirals Lady, who could not agreed together: Thee two Rivals being almot always in Company, envyed one another's Joy and Affliction. In hort, being always at Enmity, they parted, and Yolanda went for her <>
and that of her Mother-in-law to remain at a Relations Houe from whence he ent daily to enquire after the Health of the Prince,
whom Camilla alone had the Priviledge of viiting. She came to ee him with the King, who knowing that her Affection would ooner or later degenerate into Friendhip, and endeavoured already to give Occaion for the contracting it between them. The Princes his Daughter contributed thereto on her part, and being deirous to expell Love from her own Heart, he no longer ued any Terms that are proper to it; and aid nothing that might give Occaion to any uch Motions. The words of Friendhip were the only ones in their Mouths; and Camilla not caring, tho Love appeared to her under a borrowed Name, provided it was till the ame in the Soul of Frederick, did uffer it with great Satisfaction. The Princes of Sicily was at length cured of her Fever, but he was till in a languihing
Condition; he had oberved o melting a Sadnes in Amaldee's Countenance at their parting, that it re-doubled her own. But tho that tender Trouble had afforded her ome Joy, yet it lated not long, and that Intant of Happines went away o fat, that it only helped to render that Princes more unhappy.

In the mean while, the Truce being at an end, and Berranger having a long time been preparing a coniderable Fleet, (his Son was hardly returned) when for to punih him for the Obtacles he had raied in his Deigns, he ordered him to take the Command and Conduct of it. This was a cruel Circumtance, for him to bear Arms againt a King, whoe Favours had filled him with Admiration, and againt a Prince, who had inenibly diarmed him of a
certain natural Haughtines, which was his only Defect. His budding Paion, which he did not call by that Name, did extreamly weaken in him that which his Father would have inpired him with for that War. Moreover, he found it o unjut, that he proceeded to a hundred Extremities, before he could be brought to it: however, he at Length yeilded, it being to no purpoe for him to oppoe the deigns of his Father, who for his Obtinacy inflicted the Punihment on him, of going to lay wat a Countrey he had o much kindnes for, which indeed he looked upon as o evere, that he could as willingly have been dragged to his Grave. He could not forbear telling the King, who recommended to him the doing his Duty, If I do it, you have Reaon to fear the Succes of your Enterprie. Thee
Words making the King apprehend that he might favour the Interets of Menfroy, he gave a ecret Charge to one of the Officers, to have an Eye upon his Conduct, and to give him an Account of all his Actions, and told him, that his Fortune hould anwer for the Diobedience of his Son. Hereupon, Amaldee embarqued for to return to Sicily. He wihed that a happy Ship-wrack would dipence him from a Voyage o fatal to his Repoe and his Glory.
