He had only the Name of Commander in Chief, and it was that Name that made him appear culpable in the Eyes of the Sicilians. Menfroy did very much upect the Violence that was done him, but Frederick was more difficult to be peruaded in that Cae; he thought it omething o evere,
to ee him in Arms to attach him, and which he would have done, tho it had been only in his own Defence againt him, that he could not find any Reaon for his Jutification. Beides, the Vexation he had to ee that apparently he had never had him in his Memory, while that he afforded him all his Thoughts, did very much contribute to the making him entertain Reaons of Complaint in all he could have done. Thus that Prince did not appear, though he was effectually innocent: No Body had heard from him ince his Departure from Sicily, by the Care that Berranger had taken to prevent it. This very much urpried Camilla, who knew not what to think of it. Frederick had often let her know, how much he was diatisfied with this Procedure; but
in uch paionate Terms, that he frequently reproached him with having more Kindnes for her Brother than for her. Since we are retrenched to the Names of Friendhip, aid he to him one day, give me that which you have for Amaldee, Why hould you make o diadvantagious a Difference for me? How atisfied hould I be, if I could draw upon my elf a little of that Dipleaure, which methinks is o obliging: Do not You make Tryal of that, aid he to her, omething fainting. Alas! anwered he with an extream Sadnes, It is more for my Interet than for Yours, which I ought not to neglect, You love me o little, though I love You, that hould my Affection in the leat grow faint, Yours would vanih in an intant. But, I mut confes, that it would be in vain for me to endeavour to leen it; and I am enible, that it
would be as impoible for me to merit your Dipleaure, as you to grant me it. Ah! Frederick, either You do no longer, or You never did love me, my Paion is ever augmenting and yours decreaing. And indeed, it is a great Diminihing in Love, not to encreae. Beides, the Princes of Majorca, in the beginning of her Tendernes, had o often wavered between the fear of having a Rival, and the hopes of having none, that thoe tumultuous. Sentiments did blind her as to thoe of Frederick, and hindred her, in ome manner, from perceiving their Faintnes. But, when he had her mind free from any Jealouie, he began to oberve them with more Exactnes; and finding them o little conformable to her own, he fell into a Melancholy more cruel than all the violent Griefs he had lain under.
How! aid he, I loe Frederick, and no body deprives me of him, I loe him by himelf, and it is he who refues to love me, tho he is not in love with any other Women! How happy was I, when I had no reaons of Complaint but againt my Rivals, I might accue my Star of Misfortunes, I might accue their Charms of forcing him to love, but nothing ingages him; he prefers his indifference before all the oftnes I might inpire him with; he lights me, and I can only blame him for all the hard uage. I receive from him. But the dieae was without remedy, and inupportable, they all began to ham one another in Scicily, and Amaldee's abence caued a Conternation in the mind of Frederick, which was hared by all thoe who had any concern for him. He was o out of humor, that no Body durt peak
to him: If he went out of his Apartment, it was to hide himelf in ome lonely place where he was inacceible. His Mitrees would everal times have followed him to his Retreats, but were till hindred by one another; they mutually incommoded themelves, and through the conformity of their Sentiments, they almot ever jumped in the ame Deigns: Thus was he freed by all together, from each of them in particular, and he found himelf les importuned by the Multitude, than if he had had but one. However, tho they all perued him with an equal Paion, the Admirals Lady was the mot happy to find him alone; He hunned her the leat, becaue he did not know that he was his unknown Votary, whom he wihed might be o to him for ever; though he had een her often with Camilla and Yolanda,
in places where they came upon his account, he had not taken notice of it; he had ever looked upon her to be too avere to Galantry, for to entertain any uch upicion, and imagined, when he perceived a return of kindnes in her for him, after all the incivilities he had committed, that her Husband had made her a Confident of what he was. This thought eemed to him o probable, that he reolved to make her his Confident. It was requiite he hould have one: When we are happy, we contain all our joy within us, and can be without imparting it to any Body; but when we are afflicted, we mut necearily dicharge one part of our grief by confiding it in a Friend. He looked upon the Admirals Lady as a very good Woman, imagined that he would willingly embrace all his
Sentiments; and as they had reciprocally the deign of meeting, it was not long before they did o. One day Frederick went into an Alley, where he found the Admiral's Lady, they walked together for a while, and after the firt Civilities, which lated but too long in both their opinions, Frederick began firt a particular Converation. Madam, aid he to her, I have extreamly ought an occaion to find you alone, and you have not eemed to hun it; I give you a thouand thanks for all your favours. I have of late perceived a change in your Carriage, which makes me believe that you know omething of my Secret. The Admiral's Lady was very much urpried at the change of his repectful behaviour, and did not take it well that he was reproached with having o much kindnes, which he had never
dreamt he was liable to. Her face hewed her to be extreamly troubled, and he told him with ome kind of Anger, Methinks that you ought not to abue what pity has obliged me to do: And the diorder he was in hindring her from continuing, Frederick not comprehending her dipleaure, told her, Madam, I did not think that a Confeion, which hews the eteem I have for you, could have given you any offence; but ince it dipleaes you, I hall ay nothing more. The Admiral's Lady being mortally afraid he hould hold his peace, told him languihing; Speak, Prince, I will lay aide omething of my everity, ince indeed I know but already too much not to hear the ret favourably. The Princes was more and more perplexed, and could not comprehend the meaning of that everity and that favour which were
valued at that rate, and thinking that he herelf was obliging in that he had choen her to the prejudice of any other, to honour her with her Confidence, he thought her very fantatical. However the occaion he had for One whom he might open her heart to, made her pas over all, and he was going to tell her a thing which would have produced terrible Conequences in that Conjuncture. The Admiral's Lady would have proclaimed a Mitery which mut have filled her with pight, and all the meaures that the King had taken hould have been broken, if his good fortune had not made him end one of his Attendants to eek out Frederick, to give him notice that Berranger's Fleet was coming with full Sails under Amaldee's conduct. The peron who was charged with this Commiion, performed
it omething rudely. What a urprie was this to the poor Princes! What conflicts did he not undergo! The laughter and horrour which he repreented to her elf, might well have daunted a young peron; but nothing terrified her o much as the danger whereto Amaldee was going to be expoed: She was no longer mindful of his lights, her greatet mifortune was to loe him by his death; and all Sentiments being confounded in that, I mut be gone, aid he adly, turning towards the Admiral's Lady, tho I have not yet, Madam, unboomed to You my thoughts. I know enough, Prince, aid he to him, hedding ome tears which Frederick found very obliging, and for which he thanked her by a ign of his Head, which he found more obliging than all he could have aid. Whereupon he
went away to the King, who expected him in his Cabinet. He had a mind to be alone with his Daughter, whom he aw very much alarum'd, which did not at all urprie him, and interpreting her timidity like a good Father, he was long in upence if he hould uffer her to be expoed to the dangers of a Sea-fight. It was however requiite to continue a Fiction that paed for a Truth, and was o important to the repoe of his People; Thus he found no reaon that could dipene his Daughter from paing for his Son in the War, ince he had ever appeared under that name at Court: Wherefore he deired her with tears in his eyes to preerve her elf, and to be more mindful of what he was, than of what he ought to appear. Why do not You incourage me better, aid he to him, being
charmed with the kindnes he hewed her, it will be but too eaie for me to appear what I am, and I ought at leat to eem Frederick in o great an Occaion, though I belie that name in my own Soul. Ah! my dear Daughter, be careful only of the Princes of Sicily; Frederick will ever be well enough preerved. They parted, being both full of all the Events which they foreaw. But Camilla having had notice of all that paed, was extreamly concerned. Her Brother and her Lover were going to engage, and he aw afflictions falling upon her, what ide oever Fortune hould favour. She went to Menfroy, and asked him pardon for the Ingratitude of her Brother: That good King was altogether dipoed to excue him; they eaily believed, knowing him as they did, that he mut be under a great Contraint,
and rather pitied than blamed him. All things were made ready, and Menfroy's Fleet being equal, or indeed rather tronger than that of Amaldee, he reolved to go out and prevent his Enemies Attack: Beides confiding in the jutice of his Arms, and in the good luck which had never abandoned him, he ent a Herald to the Prince of Majorca, for the chooing a day fitting to decide their quarrel. Menfroy choe rather to hazard an Engagement by Sea, than to fatigue his People by a long War, which would have interrupted their Commerce, inomuch that the day was appointed for the Battel. Camilla had not of a long time een Frederick in particular; there had paed ome kind of Coldnes between them, which eaily happens when Affections are not reciprocal. As all
their Dicoure was now come to be of indifferent things, he took an occaion to ask him what he thought of her Brother, and if his procedure did not inpire him with a great averion for all their Family; for he durt no longer tell him, that he apprehended it as to her own particular: Madam, aid he to her with a very tender Air, You would eaily know my thoughts, if you knew me a little better: This was ufficient to engage her to an Explication, which he had o much deired. It is eaie to judge that they then were reconciled; Quarrels eldom lat long when there is a dipoition on both ides to put an end to them, and when we once come to clear Supicions, we often end by Jutifications. Thus Frederick, before he departed made his Peace with all his Mitrees. Yolanda
alone had not an opportunity of peaking with him; but he thought of him the more, and fancied that he thought no les of her; and indeed, never did Mitres o much rely upon the Faith of her Inclination. It gave her o great a tranquility as to Frederick, that an Infidelity on his part would never have eemed probable to her. Hereupon he went on Board his Ship, being very uncertain what he was to do; and Menfroy having embraced him with a tendernes that eemed a fore-knowledge of ome Misfortune, they eparated, the King leaving him the Command of one of the Squadrons of his Fleet under the Conduct of the Admiral, and he himelf Commanding in Chief over the whole, boar up in all diligence againt Amaldee: When this Prince, who was expecting
him in good order, had perceived him, he ent at the ame intant one of his mot coniderable Officers in a Pinnace, for to tetifie to him the great regret he had to appear in that Equipage, and to how o much ingratitude in appearance, tho he was only unhappy in effect. Menfroy ent him a generous Anwer, That he was not at all urpried that he obeyed the Orders of his Father, and that the Actions could not be Criminal when the Intention is Innocent. Thereupon he ent him back; and thoe two Princes thought of nothing but of doing their duty. The Engagement was very bloody on both ides; the principal Squadron of the Sicilian Fleet put a great part of that of Amaldee's into diorder, who coming to rally and econd them with the Squadron which he commanded in Peron;
He found Menfroy in the Head of them, and was willing to hun him; and the King of Sicily being unwilling to attack him out of the ame motive, turned his Fury upon the ret of the Enemies Fleet, the greatet part whereof he took and unk; and after five or ix hours Engagement, he gained at longth a great Victory, being the ame Fate that had always attended him; but it cot him very dear, ince that Frederick and the Admiral were not to be found amongt the Conquerors, inomuch that it was very much doubted, whether Berranger or Menfroy had received the greatet los. The thing happened in this manner.

Amaldee, as we have aid, being deirous to pare Menfroy, knew not that in falling upon another Squadron of the Sicilian Fleet, he attacked Frederick. The Admiral
did his duty with great vigour; but as they were bearing up o near one another, as to dicern Objects, Frederick perceived the Prince of Majorca, whoe adnes eemed to attone for all the Affliction he had given him; that ight put him into uch a trouble, that he no longer knew what he did: He was o little able to defend himelf againt him, that he no longer thought of defending himelf againt others: And Amaldee fell likewie into o great a diorder that he eemed to Communicate it to the ret of his Fleet. But to what an Extremity were they not both reduced, when that the icilians being animated by the death of the Admiral, who had been newly killed with an Arrow, they grappled Amaldee's Ship, before that thoe two Princes had deliberated what they were to do,
their Souldiers attacked one another with a Fury that did ufficiently repair the weaknes of their Princes; and Frederick eeing himelf Mater of his own Conduct by the Death of the Admiral, after having been in upence ome Moments about the Reolution he was to take, on a udden repenting his Effeminacy, or rather not knowing how to come to any determination, he followed I know not what rage, which forced him to enter with his Sword drawn into Amaldee's Ship: He remained in that Confuion, that Amaldee had time to recollect himelf from his firt Emotion, and preenting him with his Sword, Generous Prince, aid he to him, Stab this perfidious heart, that has not dared to follow it's own Motions, and which could not hinder me from doing an Action
unworthy of the eteem I have for you. Frederick was o tranported with what he had done, and with what he had een the Prince of Majorca do, that giving back he made a fale tep, and had like to have fallen into the Sea, but Amaldee aved him, and neglecting all other Cares, his whole Thoughts were then full of a Peron who intereed him under a borrowed Name. He had taken him by the hand, and they remained ome Moments in that Poture, enjoying a certain Delight, notwithtanding all their Agitations, which hindred them from thinking even of the Condition they were in. Then Frederick diingaging himelf from his Hands, told him faintly, Do not upend the Effects of my Duty, uffer me at leat to go to the Defence of my Men. Alas! replyed
Amaldee to him, with an inconceivable Grief, eeing that he was going away, What Coure mut I take to do my Devoir, and why do we o obtinately purue War, when our Hearts are in Peace? Frederick was omething vexed that he had given Occaion to the peaking thee lat Words; and for which, ome of Amaldee's Souldiers uffered, that the Prince of Sicily might at leat revenge himelf on them, for the Paion their Prince had inpired him with; inomuch, that he fell upon them with an extraordinary Fury, and making his way through a thouand Swords, the Prince of Majorca was in terrible Alarums for his Life. He endeavoured to put an end to the Fight; his Party had the Advantage in that place, where the better part of his Forces was got together. The mall
Forces that followed Frederick, were over-pow'red by Numbers; the ret perihed, and were unk with Frederick's Ships, who was left alone, and abandoned in that Extremity. He looked tenderly upon Amaldee, and without deciding what he demanded of him, he inpired him at that Intant with a deire of making him his Prioner, and with a deign of etting him at Liberty. At firt, they were not able to peak a Word to one another; but at length, Amaldee broke Silence, either as he was the boldet, or that his Thoughts were at more Liberty: It is certain, that when that Love does not appear under it's proper Figure, he does not commit uch great Diorders, he is hardly any otherwie formidable than through the Fear we have of him; and tho he was in the
Heart of Amaldee as well as in that of Frederick, yet he made a much les Butle in the one than in the other; Amaldee had received him without knowing who he was, and he only gave him ome mall Diquiets, which he is not able to dipence any Body from; but Frederick, who endeavoured to oppoe his Progrees, was tormented both with the Shame of having given him Entrance, and the Deign of banihing him from his Heart. The Dieae is never o extream as when we go about to be cured; and it is in thoe Conflicts that we are to be pityed. Ah! Prince, cryed Amaldee, Why mut I needs loe you by etting you free; for, if the Friendhip I have for you makes me deirous to detain you, the Acknowledgment that I owe the King of Sicily and your elf, demands of me your Liberty:
Render it me then all entire, aid Frederick to him, being hurryed away by his Paion. You conent then to our Separation, aid Amaldee to him; and do you willingly, replyed Frederick? In hort, continued he, You will uffer me to go. Amaldee was o charmed with receiving o many Tetimonies of Friendhip, and Frederick o confued with having given him them, that they once more were urpried with Silence; but then at length, Frederick's Timidity made him break it in his Turn, and the fear of being expoed to the receiving a thouand Marks of Eteem from the Prince, which though pleaing, were o dangerous to him, that they made him reolve to deire the Prince to let him go. I perceive then you hate me till, aid Amaldee to him,
but he made him no Anwer; and fearing that he had but too well peruaded him of the contrary, he went in great Hate into the Ship that was detined to carry him home. Amaldee commanded with great Grief, that he hould be conducted to Meina, but he was but very ill obeyed; the Peron whom Berranger had commiioned to have an Eye over his Sons Conduct, gave order ecretly, for the carrying Frederick to Majorca, after having feigned, for the contenting the Prince, that he had appointed them to teer to Sicily; it was eaie to put this Order in Execution; Night coming on, did both facilitate this Deceit, and the Retreat of the Prince of Majorca, who did but too oon perceive the Defeat of his Fleet, he re-aembled the Remains as
well as was poible for him, and ecaped happily from the Puruit of Menfroy, whom Night did deprive both of Frederick and the ret of the Victory. After that Amaldee thought himelf out of his Reach, being troubled with o many Events, he hut himelf up in his Cabin, while that his Fleet made away with full Sails from Sicily, whither his Heart tended however. His Return was yet more ad than his Voyage had been, and Frederick who was no les agitated than himelf, uffered them to carry him whither they had a Mind; but when he perceived the Trick that was put upon him, he gave a doleful Skreek, and likewie fell into a Paion againt thoe who ued him o treacherouly; but there was no Remedy.

He perhaps found likewie a kind of Conolation in thinking that he hould again ee Amaldee, without having contributed thereto; He was very glad that his Enemies had done for him what he never durt have done for himelf, and though he eemed to be in a rage, without doubt he lay under no great Violence. They had neither of them the leiure to be weary during their Voyage, their Thoughts took them o up, that they made them imagine it very hort. They arrived at the ame time at Majorca, and Prince Amaldee not knowing that Frederick was o near him, went to alute the King and Queen, who made him a very unkind Reception, they were very much grieved to ee that Detiny continued obtinately bent upon their ruin, they knew nothing of Frederick's
being taken, and the atonihment was equal between them and Amaldee, when it was told a moment after, they then were full of Acknowledgment to the Prince, their Son; the Peron who had managed the Buines, had a great Repect for his Prince, and eeing that he had been contrained to dipleae him out of obedience to the King, he was willing to repair his Fault, by giving him the honour of all. In private he made him his Excues for that deceit, and after having told him the Reaons which obliged him to it, he found him dipoed to pardon him, thus all the World was atisfied. The King had never been enible of any Joy equal to that of having the Son of Menfroy in his hands, He deired to ee him; and that Prince having paid his
Repects to him, with a very good Grace, and having entertain'd him with a great deal of Wit, he was omething ecretly vexed, that his Merit was but too anwerable to his Reputation; but the Queen had far other Sentiments, he relihed a double pleaure in having him for her Prioner, when he found him o well made, and obtained from the King her Husband, that the City hould be all his Confinement, hoping to make him loe the Liberty he gave him, whereof Frederick on the morrow had ome upicions, and in a few dayes after, he imparted to him her Thoughts. Years had not yet extinguihed her Beauty, he was addicted to Gallantry, and imagined that he might well merit Vows, without exacting them, he was forced ometimes however
to make Advances; Her Rank hindred her at leat from knowing the Lovers whom he caued to languih, and did trangely importune her, upon Frederick's account, who entertained her with a thouand agreeable things, for he had recovered all his Gayety, and he lived in o perfect an intelligence with Amaldee, that his Felicity hindred him from thinking that under the Name of a Friend, he was a Lover, and that her haughtines was but ill managed; and indeed, Women never think of that, when they are atisfi'd with their Lovers, and the deign of being evere, does eldom arie during the pleaure of a happy Engagement. His was in a fair way to become o, Amaldee did inenibly hew him as much tendernes as if he had known
him better; he might believe that it was ympathy which occaioned their Inclination; and as he was entertaining him with a thouand kind things, being prompted thereto by motions which he could not penetrate. Word was brought that the Queen deir'd to peak with the Prince of Sicily. At firt their Converation was very diverting, the Queen had a great deal of Wit, and Frederick had no les; at length they made Love the Theme of their Dicoure. For my part, aid Frederick, I believe that the Perfection of Love conits in its continuance, and that We may judge of its force, when it can reit Time; and I, replied the Queen, hould believe on the contrary, that Contancy does rather proceed from the weaknes of a Lover, than from the power of Love. There are ome, aid he,
who have not the courage to change, who make a Habit of their Paion, which becomes calm and till, does omething approach indifference, and has no longer any more than the Name of Love, the Pleaure is greatet in having new Sentiments. This is the reaon that mot commonly Amorous Ingagements are only delightful in the beginnings. You, aid he, ought to lay by that o regular Fidelity, your Peron is attended with an Air that may pretend to more than one Conquet; it is only for thoe who have but a mall hare of what can pleae, to keep to their firt Paion, though they are o happy as to be therein uccesful, they ought never to hazard themelves in a econd: but there are People of o great Merit as to entertain more extended Deigns.

Frederick received very Civilly the application he was pleaed to make him of thoe obliging words, but the Queens dicoure having a particular Aim, whereto he only Anwered in general Terms; Could you make ue of thoe Maxims, aid he to him looking upon him fixedly, examine your elf and in time you hall know more. Hereupon he withdrew into his Cloet, without expecting her anwer, perhaps for fear of receiving one, that would not be very conformable to what he too ardently deired not to be under apprehenions, and perhaps likewie to conceal her Bluhes; for how much accutomed oever a Woman is to intrigues, he always Bluhes at her loving firt, be it out of hame or pite. Frederick remained very much urprized, and foreeeing that the Queens
Paion would give him ome trouble, he was a while in upence, if he hould give a hint of it to the Prince of Majorca, perhaps by that means they would have come to a more entire explication. The Conjuncture was favourably, but they were detined to other events, and the clearing of this buines was deferred by an interreed Peron. Frederick was expecting Amaldee who ued to Walk with him every Evening, and had hardly made four teps, than that he was overtaken by a young Cavalier, who made himelf known to be the Admirals Widdow. His urprie was great, How, Madam, aid he to her, my Eyes deceive me without doubt: No, aid he to him, Your Eyes do not deceive you, and beides, if your heart did tell you that it was me, you may very well
rely on its Tetimony: but by what good Fortune, aid he to her, do I ee you again? Can you doubt of that, aid he to him, let it be only in conideration of you, if you could do the ame thing for me? Frederick was o amazed, that by having only offered to make her his Confident, it had obliged her come o far; and was no les urprized at the Compliments he made him, joyned to that trange diguie, that they were going to fall into a new perplexity, if Amaldie had not diverted them from it. But it is time to make known by what Adventure he came to Majorca; it is certain that when a Woman, who pretrends to more than ordinary Virtue and Severity, does concern her elf in Gallantry, he does not do it by halfes, but paes from one extremity to another; and
when he reolves once to tray out of the coure of Widom, he eldom contains her elf from committing extraordinary follies?

But for the taking a Propect of things from the time we left them in Sicily; you mut know, that after the Fleet was returned Victorious, although in Conternation upon Frederick's being taken, people were divided between Joy and Grief, every one was enible of their particular loes, and it was enough that they did not afflict themelves with the Princes imprionment, ince they were aured of his being alive, without that rejoycing at the gaining a Battle, which Sicily paid o dear for; everal coniderable perons had lot their Lives therein and amongt others, the Lord High Admiral, as we have
aid was Killed. His Widdow, whom he left in right to dipoe of her elf, reolved to make ue of it in favour of her Lover: he had apparently a very enible Grief for the Death of her Huband; and people were not urpried at the Reolution he had taken to leave the World, but he had not yet renounced its Pleaures, which he till found was not without Charms: he was only obliged to go eek them afar off. The Object of her Delight was now at Majorca, and he reolved to pare no endeavours to find him out. After that the firt Ceremonies of Mourning were over, he pretended to retire into a Convent. In the mean while Camilla knowing Frederick to be at Majorca, had a great deire to return thither, and did not think it convenient
to tay any longer in the Dominions of an Enemy againt the Will of her Parents, he went to the King and told him, that it was not Jut, that Berranger's Daughter hould be well treated by a Prince, whoe Son was in the hands of her Father, who did not retore him that Liberty which he had given Amaldee. I ought not, aid he, to hare in his ingratitude, by uffering it: I am ohliged to make it my whole endeavour to et the Prince at Liberty, end me back to Majorca, if you can confide in me. Without doubt the King my Father will at length be melted with o much Generoity: But in Cae he continues Obdurate, notwithtanding all your Favours, leave me to manage this buines with Addres, and I promie, you that you hall ee him again in a hort time, or that I will
come and remit my elf into your hands. Perhaps he did really mean all that he had poken: But Memfroy without much conidering her intention, told her, Madam, provided that your intrets may till be preerved, I hall not be orry to be obliged to you for the Liberty of my Son. He had already caued an offer to be made Berranger to render her upon very advantagious Conditions, but he would in no wie hearken to it. Nothing was o advantagious to him, as to have the Prince of Sicily in his Dominions; inomuch that Memfroy deparing of eeing him without renewing a War, the ucces whereof is ever doubtful adventured to end back Camilla, and delivering up voluntarily an Hotage that Chance had given him: He fancied that he hould thereby oblige Berranger to retore
what Fortune had given him likewie. Inomuch that all things being prepared for Camilla's departure; he was ent back with a Noble Convoy, and the Admirals Widdow taking that opportunity to go to Majorca, did mingle her elf in the Crowd of thoe who accompanied her. She Tranveted her elf into a Cavalier, and was o well diguied, that he hardly knew her elf. Several days paed without any ill ucces in her Deign. Camilla was almot ever hut up in her Cabin with one of her Maids, in whom he mot Confided, and without doubt the Admirals Widdow would not have been Dicovered, if her Love had not betrayed her. The Character of a Lover is too remarkable not to be ditinguihed. She bethought her elf of making an Acquaintance
with the Princees Confident, hoping to know by that means, in what terms Frederick tood with Camilla, though the Admirals Widdow did believe her elf beloved: There needs o little to wound a Paion, that incertainty has ever been the hare of thoe who are in Love. Thus he did all he could to have a clear Information; he thought, that the bet coure would be for her to win the Heart of that Maid, for the dicovering of her Mitrees Secrets; and as nothing renders People o dextrous as Love, he acted the Lover o naturally, that this Confident took delight in believing that he inpired her with ome tender motions. The habit of hearing amarous Dicoure, had prepared her Heart to entertain thoe oft and tender Vows; and the entiments
of the Princes, had eemed to her to be o weet, that he could not forbear following them. The Admirals Widdow made a very pretty Gentleman, and eemed very deerving the Ladys Favours. Thus a great progres was made in the Heart of that Maid, when unluckily he had a deire to peak of her Galant. It is impoible for People to forbear tarting in all their Dicoure, omething of the Object their Soul is full of, and we ometimes meet with uch Perons, who had rather peak ill of their Victorys, than be contrained to ay nothing at all of them. She was ever hearing Camilla commending hers, and it is no mall contraint to be always hearing, when we have o many things to ay. She could not forbear breaking o troubleome a ilence, which he did o
dextrouly, that he both found the means to pleae her Mitris, and atisfie her elf at the ame time. The Admirals Widdow had often talked to her of Frederick, and the Maid made ue of that pretext to peak in Commendation of her Galant, Madam, aid he to her, I know a Sicilian here on Board, who has a mot particular Affection for his Prince, and I dare aure you, that he is the mot zealous of his Subjects. Camilla was too tender not to be Charmed with the affection that people had for Frederick, we think our elves indebted to others for the kind entiments they have for what we love, and he was willing that the pretended Sicilian hould know, how kindly he took his good will. Her Confident was upon the wing to call him, but at firt he made ome
reitance, yet being obliged to obey, he diguied his voice o well, that he was not known, till peaking of Frederick, a bluh urpried him, and it was eaily perceived that he tudyed what he had to ay: his dicoure had no relation, the one part with another, his Motions appeared in their Naturals, and his true tone of Voice returned on him. The Admirals Widdow was too incere upon this Subject, for to be able to conceal any thing from Jealouy. Madam, aid he to her, I thought you very buy in Works of Piety, but the Habit of a man which you have put on, does not peruade me that you have had any uch Motive. The Admirals Widdow made her a very mart Anwer, for there is no keeping of rank amongt Rivals, and the Conformity of Sentiments does
in ome manner equal perons; their Converation was very bitter during ome time, but at length they were appeaed being there was no Remedy, and agreed; hoping to deceive one another, to demand a Confeion before their Faces of the Prince of Sicily, and that the Mitris, who was preferred hould enjoy that happines without the others envying it her; Whereupon they concluded together, that the bet way would be to urprie him, that he might not have the leaure to Correct his words, but explain himelf in good earnet, but they reolved both in particular to prepoes him in their favour. Rivals never keep their Words, and Love removes all manner of Scruples. The Admirals Widdow found him out firt as has been already intimated, but he made no advantage
of her diligence, for though he was not hindred by Camilla he was o by her Brother who came to tell him ome News; The Admirals Widdow withdrew not being willing to be een in that poture which was o little Conformable to Modety, otherwie then by him who had occaion'd that extravagance, and who ought to be the more obliged to her for that he had urmounted all manner of Coniderations for the love of him. But as we have not all thee Coniderations for others, we are careful to keep up the reputation of all our virtue with them, and willing to have them think us till the ame. In hort the Prince of Majorca acquainted Frederick with the digrace of his Siter, who had met with unkind reception from the King, and one much wore from
the Queen, Who upecting the occaion of her return, had forbidden her to tirr out of her Apartment. After which he imported to him a piece of News, which put him in depair, without his Comprehending the reaon thereof. The King had ent for the Princes of Mantua the Queens Neece, under Pretext of keeping her Company, but indeed for the concluding a Match between her and Amaldee. This Prince had ever hown a very great averion for any uch ingagement, but it was hoped that the Charms of that Princes would by degrees vanquih that indifference, the King gave him notice that very evening of this deign, that he might contribute thereto, and told him that he would grant him ome time for the producing between them what makes a
happy Union: Frederick was no les troubled at this News than Amaldee. They remained both of them mute, and looked upon one another without aying a word, the King and Queen being in the ame place with all their Train: the Queen found Frederick in a very great trouble, which he did not doubt, but that Camilla had given occaion to, and that thought putting her into depair, he gave the King to undertand that it was requiite he hould be upon his Guard, that the Sicilians under the pretext of having brought Camilla, might facilitate to Frederick the means of evading, and Conducting him into his own Teritories; Thee reaons were thought very probable by the King, and diffidence uting with his natural humor, Frederick
was guarded more trictly, which digrace he upported with coniderable patience, and indeed he had other misfortunes which lay much heavier upon him. He perceived that his ill Fortune had only made a truce with him for a moment, to the end, that he might be the more enible of all the afflictions that its return was preparing for him. The Queens paion, that of Camilla, and above all that which Amaldee was in a way of being engaged in, made her find a great unhappines in all the others, it was however a kind of advantage for him, that he had all thee misfortunes together, if he had had them eparately, they would have been more afflicting, but when the mind has o many views, it fiexs upon none, and it has of its ufferings only
a confued Notion which is not o violent, and indeed he was only dejected. But the Queen was more agitated, the thoughts of having caued the leat trouble in what he loved, made her inceantly contriving the means of puting him out of pain. She only waited for a favourable occaion to peak thereof to the King, whoe humor was difficult to be managed, but he ordered her buines o as to find it. She could no longer forbear eeing Frederick, her Jealouy was mollified by time, and he knew no other trouble than abence, which unhappines he was to endeavour the removing, whereupon he remontrated to Berranger that it was glorious to leave Frederick upon his word, that he would oblige him, by Treating
him honourably to make the like returnes, that he ought not to render himelf odious to his people, by an action oppoite to Royal Virtues, and that in hort, the bet coure would be to engage him to them, and to divert the trouble he lay under in being detained from his Dominions by rendring his abode with them as agreeable as could be. The King did comply with thee Intances, having nothing more to fear from the Sicilians when he had ent back with order to tell Menfroy, that if Chance had put Frederick into his hands, as it had done Camilla into his, he would have delivered him after the ame manner, but having purchaed him with the bloud of o great a number of his Subjects, and by the los of a Battaile, it was fitting he hould
till keep what he had o dearly acquired. The King of Sicily perceived that he mut till ricue ome more of his men for the recovery of his Son, and prepared anew for War, but Frederick eeing himelf freed from that great number of Guards, notwithtanding his dejection, he enquired after Amaldee, he was told that that Prince was gone to meet the Princes of Mantua with a coniderable part of the Court. How fatal was this News! He was not able to view his misfortune in that ditant Propect, though it makes it appear les great, he aw it approaching, and was in no les perplexity how, to come off from a Viit that the Queen exacted from him; and yet, however he was obliged to make it, but he went to her with o great a adnes, that the Queen
asked him with urprize, from whence that profound Melancholly proceeded, You ought to lay it now aide, aid he to him, ince your misfortunes are now blown over. Ah! Madam, aid he to her, I am no ooner got out of one Labyrinth, than that I fall into another, I am o accutomed to that long train of misfortunes, that I will alo accutom my elf to bear them with an equal Countenance: I have made a habit of my Troubles, which will caue me at leat to receive indifferently all that is till prepared for me: And will you view your good fortune alo with that indifference, aid he to him. It is beyond all appearance, replyed he, that though it hould be offered me, I hould never believe it real, and hould refue it for that reaon. Camilla's Confinement puts you into this ill humor, aid the Queen to
him, outraged with Spite, but you would do well to diingage your elf a little on that ide, from whence you are not to expect any great ucces; think of it once more, added he ri •• ng. He made her a profound
• ow, and withdrew, eeing Company come in, without making Reflection, upon what his too little obliging Conduct with the Queen might produce.
