div.head: THE FEMALE PRINCE; OR, FREDERICK OF SICILY.
PART III.
div.p:
FRederick no other Propect now, than the Marriage of Amaldee; he Walked Penive all alone, and tho impatient of his return, yet it was not long enough deferred in his Opinion. He could
not ee but too oon the Princes of Mantua, he eemed to him o Beautiful, and Amaldee o Complaiant, tho he only did what meer Civility required, that he perceived his grief was capable of increaing. The King received her according to her Quality, and the views he had for her, did merit. Yet the Queen did not ee her that day, and gave out that he was Indipoed. But the Princes of Mantua viewed Frederick with great application, and hardly took any notice of all the honours that were done her. She could have wihed that he had been the Prince of Majorca, and tho' that Amaldee was admirably well made, he was not detined to have thoe Sentiments for him, which he began to have for Frederick. They had conceived a great eteem for one another, but
nothing more, and never two hearts were at that ditance, when they were to have been united. they met, it is true, at the ame point in what concerned Frederick, but that was not the way to join them. On the Morrow they were each of them full of uch Capricious Sentiments, that it eemed as if Love had changed place for the better exerciing his vengeance, but this Princes did till bear the ource, and all afflictions were mean in comparion of hers. She had a enible redoubling of them, through the Jealouie he had of Amaldee, which he had hitherto been unacquainted with; and that o violent paion in all others, was only doleful in her, and by conequence much more oppreing. It is a great cae when we can complain of a Peron with Jutice: And
thoe terrible Motions, which makes us believe that we hate him who loves a Rival, are more upportable than thoe tender languihing, which only tends to the accuing our elves of all our Sufferings. Ah! how feeble is that Accuation, and how Afflicting at the ame time? Why did I not make my elf known, aid he, before he made his Addrees to another, it is now too late to how him the Princes of Sicily, after he has een the Princes of Mantua, and that he has already received the impreion of her Charms? Why did I not take the opportunity of gaining his heart, during his happy indifference: I complained of this, alas! but I till deferred the procuring being beloved. I ee my elf now prevented. Why did he not keep to that indifference which he would not quit for me? I never had any other
than the trouble of not being beloved, but that eeing him Love anther is a thouand times more Cruel. She was not able to go abroad that day, and pretended a icknes which he had only in her mind. The Queen was very well again, when there was an occaion to viit Frederick, who though he had offended her by his faint Behaviour, he found the means of jutifying him. He had ome reaon on his ide; the unjut proceedure of the thing wherein he might think that he had ome hare, by reaon of Camilla, was very capable of putting him out of humor: but tho all hould have been againt him, he found in her heart what poke in his defence. It is very natural to believe Innocent, what is o much our Interet to have o. In hort he dipoed her elf to make him a
Viit, after having received one from the Princes of Mantua, whom he gave to undertand, that he was obliged to have great regards for that Forreign Prince; and tho he could not approve in her elf of all the managements he had for him, he endeavoured to make them be approved of by others. The Princes of Mantua asked her everal Quetions concerning Frederick, telling her that he had not taken notice of uch a Peron, and obliged her to carry her with her; tho he had no great deire to do o. This young Princes had had a certain diquiet all the Night, which had hindred her from leeping, and which had put her into a condition of keeping her bed if he had not been to ee the Queen: he flattered her elf that Frederick's Sicknes might be omething approaching hers. She fancied
that he had viewed her very earnetly, and that he frequently ighed, while he was in her Preence, and the deire of eeing him do o again, filled her Imagination with a Delight, which vanihed at her coming into his Chamber: they found him in o lamentable a Condition, his Eyes being all bathed with Tears, which he hardly thought of Wiping away, notwithtanding their Preence. It was eaie for them to Judg, that they had neither of them any hare in that great grief. The beginnings of a Paion are not o violent, and the Princes of Mantua was with reaon apprehenive, that the Peron whom he was o deirous to render enible, was but too much o already. The Queen on her ide having no reaon to applaud her elf for that profound affliction, it made her
conceive a furious pight; the Converation was faint on all ides, and the Viit hort. As they were going away, Amaldee came likewie to make Frederick a Viit, who could not forbear giving him an unkind Reception, and though he would not willingly give him any offence, yet he did, for the Princes of Sicily imagined he robbed her of that heart, when they did not give it her, tho he had o well merited it. She could not be atisfied with him, who gave it to another. Does the Princes of Mantua end you hither, aid Frederick to him, after omething a lighting manner: Amaldee without making him any anwer upon that, asked him only what he thought of her, and if he was not very beautiful, I did not take o much notice of her, anwered he in the ame tone.
I am much afraid, aid Amaldee, now omething dipleaed, that you have een her but too much for your repoe and for mine; and that affectation of not peaking of her, eems to me a fear of augmenting that tendernes by commending a Princes who has inpired me with it. Frederick was o diordered, and in uch dipair, to ee him o inflamed, that he had not the Courage to give him an Anwer, and Amaldee was more and more confirmed in the upicion he had of his being faln in Love with his Mitres: this troubled him, without knowing the reaon of his own Thoughts. He perceived that he hould not be much concerned, tho he hould Love Frederick, but he could not endure that Frederick hould love her. I am deceived, aid he, and Jealouie diturbs my mind, I ought only to apprehend his Loving her, for fear he
hould likewie Love him: but continued he a moment after, I am enible, that I apprehend all on the ide of Frederick, even without Relation to the Princes. I am Mad, added he in hort, I am in Love, ince I am Jealous, and I can only be o of the Princes of Mantua. However, he could not conclude this in good earnet, and he was upended between his Reaon and his Sentiments, which he could not accord, but had very terrible Allarms. Frederick not being able to uffer his Rival to make all the Progres he had a mind to, while he hould amue himelf in complaints, he left his Chamber on the morrow, and appeared o ad, but o lovely, that the Princes of Mantua commended him extraordinarily, and gave Preentiments of the Truth to the Queen, whom experience rendred knowing in Womens thoughts of Frederick,
he found two Rivals, and was not her elf Beloved. This was ufficient to prompt her to terrible extremities; he was naturally Imperious: however, as Love works great changes in the minds of thoe it poees, the exces of her Paion made her undertake what he would never have done without its aid. Frederick happening to lean upon a Window, where he was profoundly Penive; he approached him under the pretext of looking into the Gardens; You are unworthy, aid he to him, of the kind thoughts ome Perons entertain of you: You ought to have perceived that I Love you: you Love Camilla, and I will give her to you: but likewie, let this extraordinary effect ingage you to ome acknowledgment. She did not wait for his Anwer; and a great Bluh covering her
Face, he went from thence to go find out the King, of whom he demanded Camilla's Pardon, and told him that his Severity ought to be atisfied, and that it was now time to take her again into his Favour. The King could hardly be prevailed with to give his conent: but after a thouand Carees, for which he had no reaon to be much obliged to her, he obtained what he demanded, upon condition however, that his Daughter hould not appear in his Preence. From thence he went to Camilla's Apartment, whom he found under o great a adnes, as would have melted with pity, any other than a Rival. The abence of Frederick, whoe Company was enjoyed by the Admirals Widdow, and all his other Mitries, was uch an affliction, as he had been ignorant
of till that time, and which he had the leiure to feel in all its extent, She received the Queens Viit with no mall atonihment: but her urprie was cruelly augmented, when he entertained her with the following Dicoure, Go thank the Prince of Sicily for your Pardon, it is to him that you are indebted for it he ets you free, by playing you an Infidelity with the Princes of Mantua, Camilla was not willing to purchae her Liberty at that rate; and the Queen went away without aying any thing more. As by breeding a quarrel between her and Frederick, he deprived her of the fruit of the ervice, which he eemingly deigned her, he was in hopes that all would turn to her own advantage. Camilla would rather have choen to have continued in doubt of what paed between
Frederick and the Admirals Widdow, than to have the certainty of his being become a Votary to the Princes of Mantua: a new Rival revives all our griefs; they augment every time we fall under them anew, becaue we add the freh troubles to thoe we had already. Penetrated with a thouand different thoughts, he only followed that which pight inpired her with, which was never to peak to Frederick. And indeed he had o much addres to avoid the occaions of doing o, that tho he hould have ought them more than he did, he would never have found an opportunity. Frederick, the Princes of Mantua, and the Queen, did o well jutifie all that had been aid, that there was no place for any doubt. The Princes of Sicily was very glad to deprive the Peron of a
Heart, who had deprived her of hers, and by that means take revenge for all the torments Amaldee had put her to, which he did with ucces. As they one day met, aid that Prince very dolefully to him, Well, you are in Love with my Mitres, mut I yield her to you? Do not yield her to me, aid he cornfully, we mut dipute for her Heart by Services; and notwithtanding the affection I have for her, mut he necearily be yours? The affection which you have for her! anwered Amaldee, Ah! this I find inupportable! How, hall I then be betrayed by my bet Friend! We mut quarrel if you Love the Princes of Mantua. Let us quarrel aid the Princes of Sicily, outraged to ee motions in him which he did not think herelf the caue of, for Love had never produced o many Caprices without making
himelf known, as he did in the Soul of Amaldee, they poke no more to one another that day, and the Princes of Sicily pending with her Rivals all the hours he would have pent with her Lover, did recompence herelf for what he might loe, becaue he was alo a loer, and he imployed her time in putting obtacles to the progrees which his Paion might make, if he could not hinder him from being in love, too happy in having o ueful an occupation! This made a diverion to her entiments, which Idlenes would have rendred more fervent. The Princes of Mantua was Charmed to ee o happy a uces in her deign, which at firt he did not think capable of being executed; he no longer made reflection upon the difficulty he had foreeen therein, ince it was
now removed. When we are atisfied with the preent, we are not inclinable to take views of unacceptable remembrances, or when we do make ome reflections upon them; our paed ufferings do only help to make us find more pleaures by the oppoition of the preent delightful entertainments. The Queen was in a fury to ee that a change had been wrought according to her Maxims, and that it was not o in her favour, he would have found it les cruel to have een that Frederick had continued to love Camilla, than to ee that he began to be in love with the Princes of Mantua, he might well have igh'd for her daughter, without giving her offence, he knew not then that he was beautiful, but after having both known her to be o, and had received Tetimonies of her Affection, to acrifice
her to another could not be without a horrible Contempt. It is particularly the preference which outrages. Camilla for her part had no other Coure to take than that of complaining with her Brother, and he of complaining with his Siter; thus they augmented their griefs by mingling them together. The Admirals Widdow who made a trict inquiry after all that concernd Frederick, was informed to the very leat circumtances of her misfortune? he became a friend of the Princes of Majorca, ince they had nothing more to fear of one another, and ince they equally did dread a Rival. They likewie concerted together the means of doing her an Injury. The Admirals Widdow could not reolve to loe the fruit of her Voyage, he would at leat peak with the ungrateful Frederick, but
he could not meet with an oppertunity; He kept the Princes of Mantua Company the mot he could, and was more frequently with the Queen than he was willing to have been, who endevouring not to make any noie, made ue of the ame Artifices he had practized in regard of Amaldee, and tole from him moments which he had deigned for the Princes of Mantua, thus was he tortured on all ides. By thee means the Queen did hare in his aiduities, or rather payed them to him, or at leat extorted them from him much againt his will. His Complaiance for her was onely contrained, nothing could move him to have any, but only in conideration of her Rank; Thus his devies having not the ame Motive which made him act for
the Princes of Mantua, they had a notable difference. Frederick had four Mitries at the ame time, he was the Lover of his Rivals, and the Rival of his Lover; and he particularly maintained thoe two lat Characters to the heighth. As Amaldee would have een without trouble, the Paion of his Mitris, if his Friend had not repaid it with reciprocal flames. He neglected very much to complain of her, he frequently entertained her only with indifferent things: but one day oberving the uneaines of Frederick, who was Walking with the Queen, and who endeavoured to approach him, to hear what he aid to the Princes of Mantua, he reolved in his turn to put him upon the Rack for ome moments, and raiing his Voice, Ah! Madam, aid he to her, have we nothing
that is more delightful to entertain our elves with, it eems as if we were afraid that Frederick hould over-hear us: as he did indeed. She made him Anwer in a kind of lighting manner, The more indifferent the Converation is, the more it ought to be agreeable: What a rigour! cryed Amaldee, in a trouble that was not feigned, ince he judged that her indifference for him, only proceeded from the affection that Frederick had for her. Is it, continued he, by uch indifferent things that the Prince of Sicily has found the way to pleae you, and has he o little accutomed you to amorous Converations, that you cannot bear with them. Frederick was too knowing in motions, not to oberve that thoe of Amaldee had a very tender Principle, without diving into the caue of that tendernes:
ince he who felt it could not dive into it himelf; this inpired him with all the rage which the Princes of Mantua ought to have conceived, inomuch that the Queen took notice of it, and was no les concerned than he. And thoe four Lovers, two of whom had only a good Title to that Appellation, hared themelves very injudicially, for want of knowing the truth of their own Sentiments. Frederick who was drawn to Amaldee, did by little and little draw the Queen to him likewie, who attributing this violence to the Princes of Mantua, he was willing to divert him, and turned uddenly into an oppoite Alley. The Converation of the Princes of Majorca, and of the Princes of Mantua, did inenibly come again to be flat and faint, when they were
no longer animated by Frederick's preence, he was not very eager to jutify her elf of Amaldee's upitions, and he fell into a certain Malancholly humour which hindred him from proceeding any further upon that point. On the other ide, Frederick and the Queen were in an inconceivable diorder, Frederick was in depair that he was no longer witnes of a Converation which he imagined to have proceeded much further; and the Queen was in depair to ee that he was o; But tho they hardly interchanged a word, yet it was a good while before they parted. The Queen detained Frederick as long as Civility would permit her, and he at length withdrew, o outraged with what he had heard, that he reolved according to the Cutome of thoe who are in love, to hear henceforward all
that he might wih never to know, he never parted from Amaldee, who innocently gave him a thouand occaions of Jealouy, he could not endure that Frederick hould peak to the Princes of Mantua, he interrupted the Converation as oon as he aw them together, the Prince of Sicily did as much on his part, thus they vexed one another by a hundred little tricks, and irritated their reciprocal tendernes by the marks they gave thereof to the Princes of Mantua; their redoubled addrees importuned her, two paions proved troubleome to hers, it was neceary that he hould rid herelf of the one or other, and without doubt the lot would have faln upon that of Amaldee, but as it was not he who had given birth to it, her power did not extend o far, and it was in vain
that he undertooke the curing him of it. As he one day according to his cutome had interrupted their converation, he ell to dicoure upon the point of jealous Lovers; for my part, aid he, I beleive that the aiduities of a Lover of that Character, do as much diminih the eteeme that a Mitrie has for him, as the devoirs of a more circumpect Lover do augment it, it is a firt ight that gives birth to an inclination, when it is happy, thoe which follow do only erve to confirme what it had already done, but when it produces nothing, all the other only help to irritate our durity, by the obtacles we are willing to raie. It eems as if he would take our heart by main force. It is born free and when it does not give it elf, nothing deprives us of it: that is very true replyed the Prince of Majorca, when
we do not pleae at firt it is in vaine that we endeavour to do o afterwards
•• contancy is as dipleaing in an unwelcome votary, as it is charming in a Lover who pleaes but when we cannot be ucceeful in Love, we are willing to be o at leat in jealouy, and it is ufficient if we can but hinder a Rival from taking advantage of our digrace, and certainly he has a greater hare in our aiduities than a mitree to whom we no longer owes them from the time that he permits them in an other.

Frederick without knowing who found o much weetnes in thee words that eying Amaldee after a very obliging manner. A dexterous Lover aid he to him, ought not to be candalized at a procedure, which howes the value which is put upon his merit and it is much for him to have procured the eteeme of his Rival. The Princes of Mantua
looked upon him at that word with atonihment and without comprehending why he tooke Amaldees part to the prejudice of his own, even in a point apparently o contrary to his interets, we may ay that he inpired her with jealouy at that moment, with more jutice than he did him and he went dipleaed away upon ome pretext, and eeing Frederick the next day in the Queens Chamber who was then taken up with ome affaires, he endeavoured to approach him and told him I know not I mut confes why you have more reguards for a friend, who ought no longer to be o, than I have for a Lover, whom I ought to manage by a thouand reaons, what would you have me do, aid he to her, he treats me very Civily he has been my Conquerour—Ah aid the Princeces
interrupting him, do men ever think themelves obliged for any thing to a Rival? you do well deerve that after your examples. I hould make him kind returns for the deigns he has upon me, however I am willing to give you another, ince you want one to hew you the devoir of a Lover, treat him as I treat him, this is no great requet; But, Madam, replyed he to her, hould I be ungrateful to that Prince whoe entiments are o generous? But, replyed he again, I never aw any like yours, and I believe that you love your Rival better than your Mitres; They could not peak a word more, for the Queen returning with precipitation interrupted them. In the mean while Amaldee and Frederick continued to treat one another with a thouand Civilities,
and always in the preence of the Princes of Mantua, they were ever in her Company, it was to no purpoe that he forbid Frederick to be o obliging to his Rival, he was Commanded by omething more powerful; they fell often out and was as often reconciled, for the opinion that he was only jealous of a Rival, made her Condemn all her motions as ridiculous, but our true Lovers could not be long in good intelligence amongt o many diorders. It came into Amaldee's head to proceed to an explication of all thee trange inclinations he was enible of. He Communicated his deign to Frederick, and told him that it was requiite that they hould put an end to their differences, by examining all their mot particular thoughts with the Princes of Mantua, and
that he who was found to love her bet, hould be left to purue his Amour all alone without any obtacle from the other. Frederick had found the time of their intelligence o weet and o hort, that he was willing to continue it, and endeavoured to oppoe Amaldee's Curioity, which gave occaion to new explications between them. Frederick reproached him, that he violently loved the Princes, ince that he was o deirous to be ure of her entiments even to the rique of not being the happy Lover, Amaldee likewie reproached him with injutice in thinking himelf beloved, and yet to uffer him to continue his addrees to no purpoe. It is too much, aid he to him, to tye me likewie to your tryumphing Charriot, thee terrible words had like to have killed
the Princes of Sicily, he had never heard her elf talked to with o much haughtines. Amaldee himelf was urpried at what he had aid, and tho he found nothing in them but what was reaonable; yet as it were againt his Will, he was o orry for what he had aid, that he was thinking to have asked him pardon, for not having offered him his Mitris, and that he had treated him like a vulgar Rival: Then Repenting on a uddain without any excue, he reolved to perue his firt deign, and taking Frederick along, who was not capable to reit him, nor peak one word, they entred together into the Princes of Mantua's Apartment, and finding her alone, Madam, aid he to her, it is time that I ceae being mierable, or that I be o for ever; peak Madam, mut I conent to the
nion of your hearts, peak Frederick, aid he to him, hedding ome Tears, do you Love the Princes o much, as not to be able to ee without trouble the Marriage we are detined too? At thee cruel Words, Frederick was not able to upport all his grief, but fainted away; yet People being called into his help, he came to himelf at length, but would not peak to the Prince of Majorca. This adventure was known by the Queen, whoe Paion did dayly augment, and who having in vain eayed to get Frederick wholly to her elf, reolved to end him quite away. She thought it would be better to deprive herelf of his ight, than to ee him the Lover of another. Inomuch that he went to the King; We always deferred, aid he to him, the retoring Frederick to Memfroy, through reaons of Policy which we
thought good, but eeing at preent that his Amours tend to our diadvantage, I think it much better to deliver him into his Fathers hands, by reaon of o many troubles, that may attend his longer tay here. Berranger made ome difficulty to yield to this Propoition, but he knew o well how to repreent o lively all the Misfortunes which accompanied them, during all the time they had made War againt Menfroy, that he was at length of her Opinion. However, as oon as he found o little obtacle in her Deigns, he began to tremble for the Execution; the Idea of Frederick's abence preented it elf to her heart with o lively a grief, that he began to Combat her own Reaons, and to find that it was a good Surety of the King of Sicily's Clemency, to have his Son in their Power,
being very enible that he hould chooe to ee him igh for another, rather than not to ee him, and finding that as long as he was in their Dominions, he hould have a kind of Right over him; the haddow of the leat Power is always accounted omething by a Mitris. She gave Berranger to undertand that it was in ome manner to be Mater of Sicily, to have the next Heir thereof in his hands, but as the interet of her Paion was not to be neglected, he thought fit to hinder the continuance of that which he had for the Princes of Mantua, by preing the King to conclude the Match between her and Amaldee; he had always deferred the peaking thereof, for fear of hewing her elf too much concerned in the thing. It is very difficult to appear indifferent when we are not
o; but that occaion was favourable, he had poken of ending him back, and he avoided mingling him in that adventure. The King had not been in the leat informed of his Paion for the Princes of Mantua, he lived with Amaldee after uch a manner as was not capable of giving any upiion to indifferent People. Thus the King was altogether dipoed to haten things, to which purpoe it was convenient to conult both Parties, The Queen took upon her to peak to the Princes, and having ent for her into her Cloet, after having made her a hundred Caraes; The Alliance which we are going to make, aid he to her, obliges me to Treat you like my Daughter. All is ready for the Marriage, Amaldee is at length recovered from his indifference, and Loves you even to the
being jealous of the incontant Prince of Sicily, who without doubt has pretended ome affection for you, for there is not a Beauty who is exempt from his Gallantrys. He was in Love with Camilla while he was in Sicily. He would likewie have paid me ome of his Amorous Vows, aid he laughing, I believe you have hared in his Addrees, and at preent I have dicovered a new intrigue. That Princes was filled with pight, when he learnt that Frederick's heart was not as new as hers, he had been ignorant of all that had paed between Camilla and him, and he was o very nice in things of that nature, that the very Sentiments he had had beforeknowing her, rendred her Jealous; he would willingly have Monopolized all the thoughts which he was capable of, as he was ready to afford him
all hers. She found no difference between having the ame addrees paid to others, that had been made to her, and between thoe that had been made to others, before any had been paid to her, ince as to her they were equally lot. And what an exces of grief was it to her, to ee that they had been hared in the little time he had received them? She asked the Queen trembling, with whom it was that Frederick had a new engagement. You are curious, aid the Queen to her with an affected gayity; It is anwered he very adly, a Curioity that I hould have for any other as well as for Frederick, but I hould not be orry to know his intregues. The Queen feigning to be of her Opinion, and of not oberving her diorder, told her, The truth is, that there is a great deal of Pleaure in dicovering
what people would fain conceal from us; for my part I interes my elf in an affair from the moment that I know it, and it affords me almot as much delight as it does thoe who have therein the Principal Part. This will be to us a merry entertainment, added he, and I will give you the means of Convicting him of Incontancy. Thereupon eeing Frederick come into her Chamber, We mut call him to us, aid he, We hall ee what anwers he will make to our Attachs. But the Princes was not in a condition to upport the ight of him, he went away under the pretext of being newly eized with a pain in the head, and the Queen applouding in her elf the ucces of her Malice, was willing to continue it; and having caued Frederick to it down, I have at length obtained for you, aid he to him,
the pleaure of returning into Sicily. That word made him turn pale, and the Queen continuing aid, The King has always had the intention of rendring you Mater of your Conduct, ince he was hurryed to ome excees upon Camilla's account, but the Marriage of Amaldee has ever poeed him ince that time, and hindered him hitherto from peaking to you thereof. As it is at preent concluded, and the Ceremonies are to be performed within a few days: you may perhaps have a mind to hare in the Divertiements that will be upon that occaion: but if you are not that way inclined, you may depart when you think convenient, if the pleaures that are preparing for that Feat are indifferent to you, and if you do not think us deerving the atisfaction of enjoying your Company for ome days longer:
But you give me no Anwer, continued he, Is not this Match to your mind? Madam, aid he to her with great violence, The only thought of parting from you, is o afflicting, that it hindered me from undertanding what you aid: but when is this Marriage to be Conummated? It would have been already Conummated, had it not been for Amaldee's backwardnes, aid the Queen, thinking to be very Malitious, for the Princes of Mantua does ardently deire it. Frederick recovered ome Joy at that Word, and Proteted o earnetly to the Queen, that he was not in Love with the Princes of Mantua, and entertained her with o many obliging things, that he remained more atisfied than he promied her elf, and Frederick was in hopes of making the Princes conent, that by acrificing
the Queen effectually to her, he might have the Liberty of eeming to have ceaed his Addrees. The intelligence, that was between them, might authorize that Thought: But all thee Projects were out of Seaon, thanks to the Queens Artifice, all his meaures were broken by the Jealouie, which he had dextrouly ininuated into the Soul of her Rival. This Princes would no longer look upon him, and it was in vain that Frederick's Eyes ought to tell her, how deirous he was of a particular Converation with her; they could not meet with hers, but having approached her Ear at a time, that no Body took notice of that action, Madam, aid he to her, endeavours are ued to make me abandon you, but I ee a change in your Carriage which if you continue much longer
will proceed perhaps to the acrificing me to the Prince of Majorca. She turned away her head cornfully without making him any anwer, and preenting her hand to Amaldee, he was obliged to lead her to her Apartment. But the Prince of Majorca did not take notice after what obliging manner he had given it him, his mind was filled with a thouand vexatious things upon her account. The King having ent to eek him, had commanded him abolutely to Marry her within eight days, which was the longet time that his reitance could obtain. He lighted her very much, and begun from that Evening to treat her as he had done him, thus they all three paed that night very uneaily. The Princes of Mantua had been o urpried at
Frederick's perfidity, that he did not think at firt of Amaldee's being faithful to her, her mind being fixed upon her misfortune, did not afford her any agreeable views; It is very difficult in a moment that a trong paion finds itelf betray'd for a Woman to think of giving birth to another, that thought came only into her head when Frederick would have been as intimate with her as before the dicovery: he then on a uddain reolved to revenge her elf, he fancied that the Prince of Sicily was proud, and that he would be loath to be deprived of his Conquet; When a Woman loes one, the deign comes naturally to make another, but it is only to make her elf the more valued by her former Lover, that he endeavours to procure a econd, who is not much obliged
by the paces that are made in his favour, ince they all relate to the affection which firt of all prevailed. Amaldee as we have already aid, did not examine all this, he had o little inclination for the Princes of Mantua; that he took no notice of her Actions, Frederick's being out of humor was capable of making him o, he could not get an opportunity to peak to him ince the adventure that had happened at the Princees, by reaon Frederick took great care to hun him, he likewie repented his having preed a Declaration wherein he took o little interet, and he found himelf more troubled at his being fallen out with his Rival, than he was pleaed that he tood in good termes with his Mitris, inomuch that his mind being full of Frederick, he wrote to him this Letter.

body.head: Amaldee to Frederick.
body.p:
I have a thouand things to tell you Prince, and you take a thouand ways not to hear them, you are as careful to avoid me, as I am to eek you; In hort I oberve in all your Actions as ingular an air of Contempt, as the eteem I have for you is particular, was ever Rival een to do as you do? When Rivals Convere together, it is till with ome bitternes, but however they Convere; but I find your ilence more depairing than all you could ay to vex me. They have ome Animoity in what concerns Concurrence, but they abate in the ret, yet you never abate any thing in yours, nor of that lighting and depiteful Carriage, which I cannot Comprehend. I am obliged to impute this proceedure
to that antipathy, which you only tifled for a while, that the revival remembrance thereof might be the more afflicting to me now. Why did you quit it, ince you did not lay it aide for ever, and that you do not now abandon it for a moment? Ah! how cruel does your friendhip prove to me, ince it was not incere. It is a refinement of hatred which you alone are capable of, however, I have in no wie deerved it, Was ever Rival een to do as I do, you are beloved, you hate me, my paion only erves to render your Victory more illutrious, I am mierable, endeavours are ued to render me happy, and I oppoe them for fear of dipleaing you, this is a refinement of friendhip which in my turn there is only I who am capable of. Alas, ince our entiments are o reembling by their force, why have
they uch different Motives: Let us lay aide that fatal equality ince it produces uch contrary effects; diminih omething of the durity of your proceedure, and I conent to augment the Civility of mine, or rather let us always meet in the ame ardour, and change only deign and if poible Conduct.

div.p:
After that he had finihed this Letter, he read it over twenty times, and did not find that it ufficiently expreed all that he had a mind to ay; he fancyed that the terms of friendhip were improper, and he could not reaonably make ue of thoe which he judged more utable. He felt great agitations all the night, which eemed to him much longer than uual, and he was very impatient that Frederick hould receive his Letter, and then again, he was afraid
that Frederick would not receive it, or that it would not ufficiently peruade him. He received it however, and it had all the effect that could be expected. It urpried him agreably, he only aw misfortunes for him on all ides, and a ray of hopes on the ide of Amaldee upended them with delight, and Conulting only his firt impule, he returned him immediately this Anwer.

body.head: Frederick to Amaldee.
body.p:
I have too much reaon to hun you and yet I do not hun you o much as I ought, but if you have ditinguihed a particular air in my flights, why have you not made a full dicovery; and why do you take for contempt, what would reemble it o little, if you would put it to a tricter Tet.
Since you make o jut a difference between my Conduct, and that of an ordinary Rival, if you examined it omething farther, you would not prefer the bitternes of Rivals, before the delicacy of a Friend, who can neither ay nor do any thing to the diadvantage of the Peron, who has merited his eteem; there would be les concurrence between us, if you did not love the Princes of Mantua, and perhaps there would be omething more agreeable, if you had been better acquainted with the Prince of Sicily, you would not demand of me to abate for one moment, any thing of what you divide o well of concurrence, perhaps you would wih the continuation of it, with as much ardor, as you now have to complain thereof, you recall that pretended antipathy, which I have but too
well undeceived you of, and whereof, however I never repented, until you had had a Mitres. How pleaing ought all my unkindnees to have been to you, ince they were not incere! but is there any refinements of hatred? Alas! thoe people hate not much, who refine in o doing; but in hort, why do you refine upon hatred, when you have a paion? this cruel hare I cannot endure; hate me as a true Rival, if you love me as a true Lover, have no reguard for me, which may be o dangerous to me; igh in repoe for the Princes of Mantua, I do not love her, ince I mut confes it; I will no longer diturb your Amours, and the propect I have given her of my paion, was only to erve for a Triumph to yours. If your Sentiments were the like as to her, we hould continue
Friends; it is only that equality which I demand, change the deign you have upon her, and I hall change my conduct with you.

div.p:
Frederick had les impatience to end his Letter than Amaldee had had. He found that he had aid too much, he was a long time in upence if he hould give it, till that a Meenger coming in from the Queen, he gave it, that he might put an end to all the reflexions it produced, he Commanded it hould be carryed to Prince Amaldee, who was not o happy as to receive it, the Peron, who was encharged with this Letter, having carried ome from Frederick to the Princes of Mantua, and receiving it in hate, he mitook what the Prince aid to him, and fancied, that he was to carry it likewie to the Princes of Mantua; he received and read it, with
all the fury that o authentick a confirmation of Perfidy could inpire her with: How! cried he, He is not atisfied with betraying me, he would likewie deprive me of the only Lover I have left; Ah! what a rage is his? I hould have uffered his indifference, if it had not been voluntary, but I cannot uffer the outrage he puts upon me; I mut punih him by what he mot apprehends. Women are particularly jealous of their Beauty, and they are often, only willing to have a Lover, for the giving Tetimony of it; he went immediately to the Queen, whom Frederick had newly left; the Queen was o atisfied with him, that he could no longer look upon the Princes of Mantua as the Rival; he was till more confirmed of the Sacrifice that Frederick had made her, by the deire the Princes
eemed to have, of becoming quickly her Daughter in Law, there was now no more obtacles in it, than what proceeded from Amaldee, who coming in at that moment, did pay all her advances with extraordinary unkindnees; the lights that are put upon a Beauty, do vex her more, than all thoe that can be done to the mot Amorous of all men; he accued Frederick with Jutice of the injury he did her Charms, and for the making him believe at leat, that he was not o contemptible, and that he received conolation for the los of him, he ent him back his Letter, with orders to ay, That Prince Amaldee had given it her, and that he made him retitution of it; this is the having o favourable an appearance, when all was contrary to her, went a great way towards
the atisfying her vanity. And indeed the Princes of Sicily was penive all alone, when his Letter was brought her, How! great was her urprie, Ah! cried he, though I do not eem a Lover, mut I needs be Treated like the mot contemptible Mitres, and mut I be Sacrificed to my Rivals. His lat troke compleats all the other, I have nothing more to hope, ince I am ued, as if I were the Princes of Sicily, I mut likewie do us he hould, and reproach that Peron with baenes, whom alas! I cannot accue of Perfidy, eeing he never loved me: Thereupon he ran to eek out Amaldee, whom he found in the Palace Gardens, and calling him all the names that rage inpires, Art thou atisfied with all thee names, aid he to him, And art thou not better pleaed with them, than with my ilence? He was
o afflicted, that he was not able to give her one word in anwer, and leaning againt a Tree, he looked upon her tenderly, and hedding a torrent of Tears, he at length drew the like from the lovely eyes of that irritated Princes, he uffered her elf to fall upon a gras-plat, over againt him, they made a mute converation, more melting than all they could have aid, but he retired as oon as Amaldee would have poken, and went into a gloomy Alley, where he met with Camilla, and the Admirals Widdow who were in puruit of her; who joined together, to ask the; reaon of the Treachery that Frederick had done them; they had for a long time tormented themleves they could no longer forbear venting their fury, and were deirount of having the cruel delight ofs
putting him ome moments upon the rack, who had made them pend o many hours in torture; they come thither together, for we are only deirous of being private, when we have omething that is agreeable to ay; Moreover they encouraged mutually one another, and pretended to put him into the greater confuion, by convicting him both together of the Treacherous Tricks, he had erved each of them in particular; they made him a Hundred Reproaches, which he could not make any anwer to, he knew himelf o well by their motions, that he was terrified, that he newly came from doing the ame thing, they would never have done talking, they found till omething to ay, and people are inexhautible, when they are to give a looe to their Paion, the
violence of their paing into their dicoures, caued them to make o much noie, as that they were heard by Amaldee, who apprehended, that his dear Frederick was engaged in ome peril, being drawn by the ighs he gave, he anwered him by others, and run to the place where there paed an adventure almot like to that he had newly been engaged in. He firt aw a Cavalier who diappeared, and perceiving his Siter all bathed in tears, Cruel Friend, aid he to him, ee the ufferings you bring upon us; Cruel Friend, your elf, replyed the Princes of Sicily adly, Why do you Sacrifice me to the Princes of Mantua? I Sacrifice you, aid Amaldee to her, I who treat her daily with o much Contempt upon your account? See, aid he to him, hewing him the Letter, what you
gave her, and which he retored to me. Amaldee proteting that he knew not what it was, did very earnetly beg of her to give him that Letter; Frederick could not reit the deire he had of eeing him read it; And Amaldee making a top at the end, how aid he to him, you do not love the Princes more than you do me? How! replyed Frederick, and do not you love her, would to Heaven that I were in a Condition to love her, Cryed they both at a time. But in good earnet do not you love her, aid Frederick to the Prince of Majorca? No, Replyed he coldly, and if I was orry that you loved her, it is apparently, becaue I do not find her aimable, but if you do not Love her, why are you in fear that I do? you mut needs have ome concealed interet; I have one without doubt, aid Frederick,
but till, do not you Love her, repeated he again, let me be ure of your indifference for her before I confes any thing: I anwer you I do not, ask her, aid the Prince of Majorca. Frederick could no longer hold out againt uch flattering appearances; and the preence of Camilla could not put a top to what o favourable a Moment furnihed him with, I have been in Love, aid he, from the moment that I aw you, and I hould till have had all my indifference, if you had never arrived in Sicily. Camilla being charmed with this dicoure, did ecretly make him reparation for all he had aid and thought againt him, but Frederick topping, found himelf in a fair way, and bluhing at what Love had made him do, he would perhaps, notwithtanding all his reflections, have aid omething
more, if the King had not interrupted him, he was amazed at his taking him aide to dicoure him, but the buines paed in this manner:

The Queen whom a too long abence from Frederick rendred uneaie, had ent to eek for him, her imagination being full of him, figured him always with another, it was neceary for her to ee him for the calming all her Supicions, he was told that he was with Amaldee and Camilla, which was ufficient to allarm her. The King being preent when this Word was brought, he bluhed at the indicretion of the Peron he had imployed, which Berranger taking notice of, he looked upon it as a very ill augure. What he added afterwards with ome kind of tranport, made him the more apprehenive. Camilla, aid he to
him, renews her Peruits, and it is very convenient to have a Watching Eye over her. Your Virtue is very Autere, Madam, aid he to her with ome didain, I perceive that you are not willing to allow your Daughter a Lover: but as for Frederick, I hall take order about him, and he may poibly be on his way to Sicily by to Morrow, for preventing the conequences of an Amour, at which your everity is o much allarm'd. Thereupon he went down into the Palace Garden, thinking upon the Dicovery he had newly made; he met there with Frederick, and breaking of the converation that had o much pleaed him, he entertained him with one that was very afflicting. Prince, aid he to him, you may poibly be urpried, that I have deferred o long the telling you that you are Free: but now hence forward, nothing
hall detain you, all things hall be ready for your going on Board, and that to Morrow, if no Body tay you here, I pretend to render Civility for Civility to the King of Sicily by retoring him his Son. And indeed Berranger had found his Glory to revive extreamly upon the Queens being in diorder, and accuing himelf of having not too well managed it: He managed at the ame time his own repoe. He paid great Civilities to Frederick, who only anwered him with a profound bow, he had not the power to thank him for a thing which puts him into depair, and for the retoring him to a Liberty, which he found would be inupportable. How enible was the Princes of Sicily's grief to depart in a time when her Preence might upport the Sentiments that Amaldee would infallibly
have entertained of her. To depart without making her elf known, or to make her elf known when he was to depart, were uch tumultuous reflections, that ome time was requiite for her to come to a determination, the Queen being no les to be pitied than he. The Idea of never eeing what we Love, is the mot cruel thing that imagination can repreent; it was requiite that he hould ee him at leat once more. Yet the King beieged continually, and the thing was almot impoible. In this preing need he was contrained to run ome rique. She Confided in the dicretion of one of her Maids of Honor, whoe Chamber he thought mot convenient for the interview, being there was a way to it by a back pair of Stairs. This Woman took care to conduct Frederick thither, who was reolved
to imploy his Credit with the Queen, being ignorant of the hare he had in that adventure. The King having et pies to watch him that Evening; he failed not to have notice given him of the way he had taken. The Queen finding her elf indipoed, had placed her elf upon a Bed of repoe, where all bathed in Tears, he aw Frederick at her knees, being as full of grief as her elf, he conjured her tenderly to imploy her credit for the deferring a departure, which would be o fatal to him: they were in that poture when they heard the Chamber door thundred open, and aw the King with his Sword in his hand: he made a full pas at Frederick, who happened to be firt in his reach: the Queen made her ecape by the back pair of Stairs, he ran to perue her, but not finding her, he
met with Amaldee and Camilla, whom we ent to the place where all this diorder paed, finding that his vengeance would be the more compleat, if all the World knew it, and that he added to it the trouble of all uch Perons as took part in Frederick, the Princes of Mantua was likewie informed of this accident, by the rumors that were pread of through all the Palace. Her tendernes was now revived, and he no longer found him culpable, ince he had now expiated his Crime by his Bloud that was hed. Inomuch that he ran thither as well as the ret; their hrieks were heard on all ides in that Chamber, and it was a very lamentable pectacle to ee Frederick weltring in his own bloud. The Princes of Mantua and Camilla embraced one another in hedding a torrent of Tears.
Thee two Rivals were no longer Enemies, and their common mifortune left them no other Sentiments, than for the lamenting what they Loved. It being neceary to undres Frederick, they withdrew, and his wound was earched. But how dangerous a one did Amaldee receive? when he aw an admirable Boom, tinctured in everal parts with bloud, yet heightned its natural Whitenes. This cannot be expreed, Love making himelf known to him in that cruel Moment, he made him feel it with all its Violence. The Princes of Sicily was Fainted away, he was thought to be dead, he no longer breathed. But Amaldee approaching her, heard her till Sigh; he having caued that heart to move again, which he had o much agitated, he opened feebly her Eyes,
and cat a piercing look upon the amorous Amaldee, and immediately hut them again. Ah! Lovely Eyes, cried he, are you cloed for ever, He imagined he had given her lat Sigh, he did the Actions of a Mad-man, and being no longer capable of governing himelf, he uffered thoe Perons to conduct him, whom the Queen had ent to give help to Frederick, to the Apartment of thoe afflicted Beauties, he did not acquaint them with o urpriing an adventure, he little thought of comforting them, or of telling them a piece of News which would only have erved to the redoubling his own depair, they were all in a gloomy ilence, which being caued by a violent grief, did lively expres it, there remained in thoe Princees a ray of hopes which tormented them
more than the entire aurance of their misfortune could have done. We uffer our elves to be tranported with rage, when the michief is without Remedy, and there is at leat but that Motion which hurries the Soul away with that Violence, and which leaves it not the leiure to be enible of all its torments: but when we are divided between mall hopes and a great deal of fear, we feel a thouand Conflicts, which as it were tore us, and cannot be calmed, but by the los of the one or other. They quickly lot them both, to make way for omething that was much more afflicting. Word was brought that Frederick had been dicovered to be the Princes of Sicily, then all the motions which they had o improperly entertained, diipating themelves on a udden, they fell into
a kind of Lithurgy, in comparion of which they found all their Allarms to be oft and pleaing. In the mean while the Princes of Sicily's wound being earched, was found not to be Mortal, which News being carried to the King, he received it as the cure of all his ills. The Queen no longer gave him any embraces, nothing hindred him from joyning the Crown of Sicily to his own, and finding his Honour ecure, and his ambition atisfied, he learnt with great atisfaction, a thing that was neceary both for his own repoe, and that of his People. He ought out the Queen to ask her pardon for his rage, and was willing to believe, that it was only to the Princes of Sicily, that the Aignation had been given, ince it was but effectually her. The Queen was o confued
with o many changes, that he knew not what anwer to make, he was in fear that it was a urprie, that the King would put upon her, and could perhaps have wihed it. Nothing was o diagreeable to her, as to learn he had no longer a Lover, and what was more that he had not had one. It was in vain that he endeavoured to render her a Witnes of that Truth, he excued her elf, telling him after a pightful manner, which her Virtue too well jutified, inpired her with, that he was even afraid, that the Princees Sex would not ecure her from his Supitions, ince her prudence had not been able to do o. Neither would the Princes of Mantua nor Camilla, now ee under the proper Figure, the Peron they had found o pleaing under one that was borrowed. They hated the
Princes of Sicily, from the time that he was no longer Frederick, but he did not remain abandoned: the Prince of Majorca gave her all his thoughts which did ufficiently comfort her for thoe he lot elewhere. What a delight was it to her to ee her elf beloved! this was a Novelty, he had never een a Lover at her feet; it is very pleaing to ee one there: but it is the highet Felicity when it is one the Woman Loves. Ah! cryed Amaldee, all tranported, Why did you wait o long to triumph over a heart that ought to be wholly yours, from the time it was capable of Loving. I have felt, it is true, ome tender longings towards you, but I lot the Pleaure by not knowing the motions of my heart, nor the merit of the Object who inpired me with them. A thouand ighs with which he repaired the time he had been
without knowing the ue of them, and a thouand diquiets he was in for her Life, did make her ufficient atisfaction for thoe he had thought to no purpoe. She had not Courage to make him languih longer without telling him what he had inpired her with. As he was one day Comparing before her the entiments he had had for Frederick, and thoe he had for the Princes of Sicily, he was willing likewie to give him a propect of her own, they took delight in examining all their mot ecret Motions, and lived already the Mot happily in the world, when that the two Kings conented to Conummate their felicity, and to make Peace by uniting their two familyes, the Princes of Mantua could not oppoe it, he had loved Frederick at a time he was to have been
Amaldee's Wife, which was ufficient to hinder her from being able to reproach him with the preference he made of the Princes of Sicily, beides that Princes had tryumphed over her heart under the figure of a Rival, for to ee her tryumph with another under that of a Mitres; Inomuch that the Princes of Mantua returned two days after the wound was given without giving the Princes of Sicily one viit, he told the King that having a deigne to quit the world, he thanked him for all the favours he had betowed upon her, and that he hould be full of an eternal acknowledgment, he was very glad to ee her take leave of her elf, the only obtacle to what he projected, being thereby removed, thus they were all well atisfied at Majorca.

Camilla recovered her Lover and a Match was Concluded between her and Prince Leon, he had ever Conerved for her a Character of o handome Paion, that he could not fail of being recompened at the end, he had voluntarily deprived him el of the atisfaction of giving her marks of his tendernes which dipleaes when a Lover is not acceptable, and he gave her a full view of it, when that the Princes of Sicily had ent for him by the permiion of Menfroy, to whom Berranger writ all that had paed, demanding of him with great earnetnes the honour of his Allyance. Leon brought Menfroy's Conent to Berranger thoe two things whom no endeavours had been able to reconcile were made friends by the interceion of their Chidreu when Prince Leon aw Camilla at the paion he had ever had received and augmented, he renewed to her his vowes which he recieved with a mot incere affection the Princes of Sicily was Charmed with that reunion, and aying one day to Camilla
that Love had made ue of her to render her more tractable; that Princes made anwer that after having examined her elf, he had oberved that the repect and addrees of Leon had at firt produced in her oul, which it durt not have dicovered but under an other Name, this being aid in the preence of that Lover, it filled him full of Joy, and Amaldee looking maliciouly upon Camilla, called to mind thoe veres, which his iter had made for Frederick at the time he thought her elf ure of his heart.

q.l: Ah! how vat are the delights
Of two hearts whom love Unites,
When in each others Breat they ee
Flames that great and equal be,
Ah! the tranports, Ah! the joys,
The blis, the ports, and Amorous toys.
Nought can in hort more weet and happy prove,
Than hearts who know themelve inpired with Love.
